prompt: I need a set of summer activities for 2 kids. My oldest is 13. He enjoys video games, arcades, go-karts, and theme parks, that kind of thing. My youngest is 11, and she's really into makeup and beauty stuff. She likes doing crafts and watching YouTube Kids. Neither of them likes sports or outdoor activities. Give me a list of 12 activities and put them in a bulleted list. Give me 8 that we can do together, 2 just for him, and 2 just for her. For each one, tell me how long it will take to do the activity and the budget, if any.  Give me 6 budget-free activities, and the rest of the activities can have a budget of no more than $50 each. Give me 2 hands-on activities that require creativity, and no more than 2 that involve screens or digital devices.
rubrics: The response should list exactly 12 activities.

Model B did only provide 12 activities.  The "additional sections" are same activities organized with the instruction constraints in the prompt. The response is not structured well, but did not a fail this criterion.
The response should present all the activities in a bulleted list format.
The response should include exactly 8 activities that the parent can do with their son and daughter together.
The response should include exactly 2 activities for only their son to do.
The response should include exactly 2 activities for only their daughter to do.
The response should include an estimated duration for each of the 12 activities.
The response should include an estimated budget for each of the 12 listed activities.
The response should not include any activity with a budget that exceeds $50.

The prompt asked for the activities that require a budget to be no more than $50. The first activity listed in model B, is a theme park day. This is under the category of "Activities to do together" The probability of 2 or 3 tickets to a theme park being under $50 is not realistic.
The response should list exactly 6 activities that have a budget of "free" or "$0".

Response A does include 6 free activities:
* "At-Home "Nailed It!" Baking Challenge" - "Free"
* "Board Game Tournament." - "Free"
* "Create a "Family" YouTube Video. " - "Free"
* "Build an Epic Fort & Movie Marathon" - "Free"
* "Library Haul & Reading Afternoon" - "Free"
* "At-Home Spa Day." - "Free"
The response should include no more than 2 activities that primarily involve screens or digital devices.
The response should include at least 2 activities that are described as hands-on and requiring creativity. For example: making crafts, creating art, slime making, DIY projects, etc.
The prompt asked for 2 but did not limit it to 2. Therefore, the models providing more than 2 creative and hands on activities is not a fail.
The response should not include a sports-based activity. For example: playing soccer or golf.
Go Karts are not considered a sport or an outside heavy activity. This is acceptable and did not cause a fail.
The response should not include a nature-focused activity. For example, hiking or camping.

The response should ensure that the two activities suggested for the 13-year-old son align with their interests in video games, arcades, go-karts, and theme parks. For example, visiting a virtual reality arcade or going go-kart racing.

The response should ensure that the two activities suggested for the 11-year-old daughter align with their interests in makeup, beauty, YouTube Kids and crafts. For example, creating homemade bath bombs or making a friendship bracelet.

prompt:
My daughter-in-law has a number of diagnoses hanging over her head, including gastroparesis, chiari malformation, and many others. She is terminal. With the gastroparesis kicking into gear, she mostly just eats baby food, and the next step is going to be a feeding tube.

This is going to pretty much be the last Thanksgiving that she's going to attempt to eat, so I want it to be a meal that she can enjoy.

The list of dietary restrictions is lengthy and problematic.
She can't have gluten, sugar, or dairy.
She's allergic to oranges, all nuts, and peanuts.

I need a full Thanksgiving menu, including full recipes, that I can feed this girl.
If I need to do something special to the dish to accommodate her, please tell me.
I want to include all the staples of the traditional meal. Turkey, stuffing, gravy, potatoes, sweet potatoes, rolls, cranberry sauce, and my daughter has requested green bean casserole. I need a dessert and a drink.

She's not going to be able to eat much, but I want everything on the table to be an acceptable option to her.
rubrics: The response should provide a recipe for turkey.
The response should provide a recipe for stuffing.
The response should provide a recipe for gravy.
The response should provide a recipe for a potato dish.
The response should provide a recipe for a sweet potato dish.
The response should provide a recipe for rolls.
The response should provide a recipe for cranberry sauce.
The response should provide a recipe for green bean casserole.
The response should provide a recipe for a dessert.
The response should provide a recipe for a drink.
Each recipe provided should include a list of ingredients with quantities. For example, 3 sweet potatoes, 1 cup diced apples, 1 tablespoon dairy-free margarine, etc.
Each recipe provided should include a list of step-by-step preparation instructions. For example, 1. Peel the potatoes, 2. Boil the potatoes in 4 cups of water, etc.
All ingredients in all provided recipes should be gluten-free or be naturally gluten-free.
All ingredients in all provided recipes should be dairy-free or be naturally dairy-free.
All ingredients in all provided recipes should be free of added sugars. For example, no cane sugar, corn syrup, honey, maple syrup.
The response should not include oranges, orange juice, or orange zest in any of the recipes' ingredient lists.
The response should not include any tree nuts, (for example, almonds, walnuts, pecans) in any of the recipes' ingredient lists.
The response should not include peanuts or peanut-derived ingredients (for example, peanut butter) in any of the recipes' ingredient lists.

The response should highlight or explain the modifications made to traditional recipes to accommodate the dietary restrictions. For example, pureeing a portion of a dish, shredding turkey extra fine, serving the center of the dish where it is the softest, etc.
The recipes should be considerate of someone with gastroparesis. For example, the dishes should favor soft, pureed, or well-cooked textures and be lower in fat and fiber.

- All prices must be under $250, completely.
- There must be a vegetarian option (not including sides)

- really, really, tired of Italian food. NO MORE PIZZA!

Here are the options. Please categorize the options by what issues they have compared to the rules in the form of a table. Please also let me know which of these options fulfills all of the requirements, if any, and then rank those ones by price:
1. Mark's Sandwiches
- 12 sandwiches, 4 all meat, 4 turkey club, 2 vegetarian, 2 bacon ranch. 12 cups of soup, chicken noodle or beef and vegetables, 2 two liters of root beer.
- Price: $249.99 (chicken noodle) or $269.99 (beef and vegetable)

- Price: $210

- Price: $210.
- Delivery: $8,  15 minutes away.

7. Cherry's

- Price: $52
- Delivery: $10, 38 minutes away.

Subject: <email subject>

Date: <insert date>

Dear: <Insert names here>

<body text>

<my name>
<my email>

My name is Andy Webb, and my email address is a.webb12345@gaggle.com

The first email (Email 1) should be sent under the title "Email 1: Progress Update Email", and the second (Email 2) should be sent under the title "Email 2: Apology Email". Both emails need to be sent on Sunday, February 4th 2024 (but all dates should be presented in dd/mm/yyyy format).

Warhammer 40k Army Categories For Your Reference:

* Space Marines: Ultramarines, Blood Angels, Deathwatch, Black Templars, Dark Angels, Grey Knights, Space Wolves
* Armies of the Imperium: Adepta Sororitas, Adeptus Custodes, Adeptus Mechanicus, Astra Militarum (Imperial Guard)
* Forces of Chaos: Chaos Space Marines, Deathguard, Thousand Sons, World Eaters, Chaos Demons
* The Xenos Threat: Aeldari, Orks, Drukhari, Tyranids, Genestealer Cults, Leagues of Votann, Necrons, T'au Empire

Email 1:

The email needs to explain that I have completed all the painting jobs for the Armies of the  Imperium and Priority Pay armies, and that these jobs will be returned to the relevant clients within a week (no date needed). The email also needs to explain that I will be completing all Space Marine and Forces of Chaos armies within two weeks from the date of the email (provide the actual two-week deadline date to reassure them). The email must name the customers and their army categories, but NOT their specific armies. This email must not mention clients with Xenos Threat armies.

The email needs to offer two apologies and explain that I am unable to complete the Xenos Threat army projects within the original agreed-upon timeframe due to personal circumstances. It must only mention clients with Xenos Threat (no other clients). The email should also offer those clients a 50% discount if they are willing to wait four weeks from the date of the email (please provide the actual four-week starting date for absolute clarity) for me to start their painting project.

The email should request that the clients reply, letting me know if they are okay with the waiting time, or if they wish me to return their army (this should be at the end of the <body text section>. The closing/gratitude section should contain the second apology.

After using the client's full names in the "Dear" sections, only use their first names in the bodies of the emails. No other text should be in bold.

prompt:
I'm the manager of a deli need to create a new temporary rota for the coming 2 weeks since we have consistent catering orders on top of our regular schedule. the clients are picking up their orders every weekday at 12:00 so I think I will have to extend all 3 shifts - half an hour earlier each on weekdays to ensure all the sandwiches for both the catering order and normal store operations get made.

Our regular shift schedules, Monday-Sunday, 3 shifts every day, 1 person per shift:
08:00-13:00
08:00-14:30
11:00-17:00

We have 4 employees: Lulu (me), Margot, Naomi, and Oona, and we are all contracted to work 26-34 hours a week. We all get 2 days off work a week. During the 2 week schedule, every employee should get at least one occurrence of 2 consecutive days off - I want to keep my employees motivated with a good work/life balance.

Since I'm the manager I will definitely have to work all the weekdays in either morning shift (08-13:00 or 08:00-14:00) to oversee the catering orders/operations. I think for these two weeks I can let myself take on more than my contracted hours to bear the brunt of the extra hours, I don't want the other employees to be too overworked, so I can work up to 36 hours a week.

Margot is the supervisor and I need to work the morning shifts with her on Thursday and Friday since they're our busiest days. Also there should be one senior staff member working at least one shift for every day of the rota to oversee operations. Oona is a recent hire so she shouldn't be put on the closing shifts (11:00-17:00) on the weekends as there are tasks we do that she hasn't been trained for yet. Also, Margot has regular appointments so she can't work the closing shift on Wednesday afternoons. Naomi has a standing agreement to work both weekend days to make sure she gets 2 consecutive days off every week so I will continue to respect that.

Can you make a clear tabled rota that I can copy into my spreadsheet with the new shifts for the weekdays?
rubrics: The response should not assign the closing shift (11:00-17:00 or the final shift) to Oona on Saturdays or Sundays.
The response should assign exactly 3 shifts (2 opening shifts and 1 closing shift) to employees for every day of the rota.
The response should use the following shifts for all weekdays (Monday-Friday inclusive): 07:30-13:00, 07:30-14:30, 10:30-17:00.
The response should use the following shifts for all weekend days (Saturday-Sunday): 08:00-13:00, 08:00-14:30, 11:00-17:00.
The response should assign each shift to exactly one person on every day of the rota.
The response should assign at least one shift to a senior staff member (Lulu or Margot) for each day of the rota.
The response should assign all employees (Lulu, Margot, Naomi, and Oona) to have at least 2 days off for each week in the rota.
The response should assign Naomi 2 consecutive days off work in both weeks of the rota.
The response should assign all employees (Lulu, Margot, Naomi, and Oona) to have at least one occurrence of 2 consecutive days off in the rota.
The response should assign Lulu and Margot the opening shifts (the earliest 2 shifts of the day), for each Thursday and Friday in the rota.
The response should assign a total of 26-34 shift hours for each week of the rota to Margot, Naomi, and Oona.
The rota in Response B is not clearly presented, with false "Hours calculation" stated below. E.g. Margot only works 22.5 hours in total in week 1 and Oona only works 24 hours in total in week 2.
The response should assign a total of 26-36 shift hours for each week of the rota to Lulu.
The rota in Response B shows 5x 5 hours shifts (each week) for Lulu which totals 25 hours per week, this is below the contracted number of hours for Lulu.
The response should assign Lulu to work an opening shift (either of the earlier 2 shifts) on all the weekdays (Monday-Friday inclusive) in the rota.
The response should not assign more than one shift to any employee on a single day in the rota.
The response should not assign Margot a closing shift (final shift of the day) on Wednesday.
The response should assign Naomi to work both Saturdays and Sundays in the 2-week rota.
The response should present the entirety of the 2-week rota in a table format.

prompt:
I need to get in touch with a few parents of my middle schoolers about their recent behavior, but my stress levels are through the roof, and I'm running out of time. Can you help me draft them up? 

There are four kids: Loghain, Cailan, Morrigan, and Leliana. I also have to send a report about them to the principal, so a fifth letter should be addressed to Mr. Solas.

Each student letter should begin with "Dear [PARENT]," so I remember to replace them. First, I want you to inform the parents about the student's main problem behavior(s), without going into details. Next, the "upside" of the problem behaviors should be highlighted. Then, say "I regretfully have to inform Principal Solas about this incident/these incidents, but please know that our goal is to help [student's name] achieve success, not to punish him/her." At the end, ask them when would be convenient for them to set up an appointment to talk about the given student's situation.

As for the letter for Mr. Solas: mention that I wrote to the parents of the students involved, list their behaviors that we need to tackle, including all the problematic instances, but don't mention the students by name. Draw his attention to the fact that we may need to divert more to funding more creative and cerebral recreational activities (besides sports). Don't mention sports at all to Solas, he likes his games. At the end, write a sentence that these recent incidents further underline my argument from our earlier conversation in October staff meeting.

Loghain: his football coach tells me that he quit the field without explanation in the middle of practice and didn't come back until recess. One of the kids may have said something to upset him from what I gather, he's not fitting in well with the team, but I also saw him heading for the library more than once. Maybe he's more suited to academic pursuits? He also skipped out on other classes, so there might be something else going on. This isn't the first time this has happened; last week, it happened twice.
Make a special mention of this above antisocial behavior in his letter in a separate paragraph, and make his request for the parents to come in more urgent.

Cailan: he didn't show up for practice at all, and when I went looking for him, I found him drawing pictures of Grey Wardens instead of changing into gear. The kid is an artist, I don't know why his parents are forcing him to play sports. I also regularly catch him drawing instead of paying attention in class, and I've seen him numerous times doing it during lunch hour instead of eating. Makes me wonder if he has time at home for such things; underline for Mr. Solas that at least one student would benefit from an arts program.

Morrigan: she keeps pranking the Andrastian Templars team members and hanging around during their practice hours in general. She'd make a great comedian, but she's just not focused on schoolwork. Every time her name crosses my desk, I have to draft one of these using different words, it drives me crazy; point is, her name frequently comes up. Just this month, Morrigan has been mentioned as a disruption no less than five times in two weeks.

Leliana: this girl has a problem telling the truth. She keeps submitting papers under aliases. I think she could be a great writer or performer, but her parents need to nip this behavior in the bud. If she's not spinning a story, she's disrupting class with singing. The kid's got talent in that area, too, but I'd like to get my sentences out without interruption every now and then. Mr. Solas should be advised that the music department could get a boost.
rubrics: In each of the four parent letters, the student's main problem behavior(s) should be mentioned concisely, without including details about each incident. For example, stating Loghain is skipping classes and practice is sufficient, without describing the entire timeline of events or that he specifically skipped football.

The letter regarding Loghain should include a separate paragraph discussing his antisocial behavior. For example, "quitting practice", "not fitting in with the team", and "skipping classes" could be mentioned.

The models were told to contradict the instruction to "not give details" in the letters drafted for parents when it came to Loghain's letter, and Response A doesn't mention any specifics about what the user classified as his "antisocial behavior" in the prompt. Although the paragraph the model wrote to fulfill this instruction ("I am particularly concerned because this pattern of withdrawal is becoming more frequent, and it is important that we work together to understand what is causing this behavior and ensure he feels supported and engaged at school") is appropriate in tone, it doesn't mention even one of the possible behaviors listed in the prompt.

Response B leaves in a lot of user instructions, and in this instance, the model specifically states:

"In a separate paragraph regarding his above-mentioned antisocial behavior:
Loghain's abrupt actions..."

This is information that shouldn't be in the final text.
The letter to Mr. Solas should state that the parents of the involved students have been contacted.

Response A is better phrased than Response B (although it's a little too flowery), but the checkers are correct: the user prompt specifically said that the letter to Mr. Solas should mention that the user had already written the letters to the parents, and Response A says that the user wrote "a draft". That seems to be indicating the AI is taking into consideration the task at hand, which it should not.
In the letter to Mr. Solas, the report on the students' behavior should mention that at least two students have skipped activities this week, without mentioning student names.
The letter to Mr. Solas should not contain any mention of sports. For example, words like "team", "football", "sports", and "match" should not be used.

The letters should decide whether the singular or plural version of a phrase is appropriate for each letter when two options are presented. For example, it should be either "this incident" or "these incidents", not "this incident/these incidents".
All four letters addressed to the parents of Loghain, Cailan, Morrigan, and Leliana should begin with the exact salutation "Dear [PARENT],".

All three checkers (the criterion checkers and the instruction following checker) marked this as an error for Model A, but I hesitate to call it one, so I marked it as minor. It's clear enough that the first line of the body of the text starts with "Dear [PARENT]", and it's understood that, if this is an email draft, the Subject line would rather relate to the student rather than addressing the parent (which the models correctly identified). The reason why I'd still mark it down for minor errors each is because the prompt didn't explicitly state that these letters would be emails, and thus, the user didn't ask for it; meanwhile, there was an explicit instruction for what the first line of each letter should be, so that does make it unasked for (albeit a harmless bonus that I don't think users would mind).

As for Model B getting an error here, the checker identifies the titles as something before the "Dear [PARENT]" formula, but that's meta-information for the user's benefit to separate each letter by student name. Therefore, in the case of Model B, this isn't an error; it's an aid for user clarity.
The letter to Mr. Solas should include the specific details mentioned about the students' behaviors (e.g., skipping class, being disruptive, dishonesty, and pranking).

prompt:
I want to improve the organization of volunteer work and increase the efficiency of all support programs in our homeless dog shelter. In order to get my proposal approved for implementing these changes, I need to prepare a report. The report will be for Greg and Megan (they oversee the project and make decisions regarding the allocation of resources and volunteer schedules).
Help me create a report that shows which tasks volunteers should perform and how to best distribute them across the days of the week, taking into account experience, preferences, and potential overload. For volunteers working several consecutive days, include adequate rest periods. Highlight tasks that require experienced volunteers and those that can be handled by newcomers.
Describe methods for training and motivating volunteers, including recommendations for handling difficult cases (for example, aggressive or sick animals) and options for rewarding active participation. If the number of volunteers is insufficient or more dogs than usual arrive, suggest how to reassign duties and resources. The report should be logical and structured, with sections clearly marked in bold and a timeline for implementing initiatives. Each initiative should show its impact on both animals and volunteers, indicate priority in terms of significance and feasibility, and include built-in success metrics, with at least one indicator measuring volunteer engagement.
Use the date format 2025-12-01 for deadlines, though it is acceptable to occasionally write dates in words for clarity. Begin the report by mentioning Greg and Megan as project overseers, and conclude with a friendly, informal phrase to convey personal regard for the team. The total length of the text should be approximately 700 - 900 words.
rubrics: The response should begin by addressing Greg and Megan by name and recognizing them as project overseers, who make decisions about resource allocation and volunteer scheduling.

The response should identify multiple volunteer task areas necessary for shelter operations. For example, it should include tasks such as feeding, cleaning, walking dogs, socialization, medical care assistance, or administrative work.

The response should provide sufficient practical detail for each task area so volunteers understand the specific scope of work. For example, if a task is mentioned, specific actions it includes should be indicated.

The response should explicitly identify which tasks require experienced volunteers and which tasks can be performed by newcomers. For example, it should indicate that administering medication requires experience while basic cleaning can be done by beginners.
The response should provide recommendations for how to distribute volunteers and tasks across days of the week. For example, it should account for differences in workload between different days.

The response should demonstrate that the distribution system accounts for volunteers' personal preferences. For example, it should mention the possibility of task choice or consideration of preferences when creating schedules.

The response should specify adequate rest periods for volunteers working multiple consecutive days. For example, it should indicate that volunteers working three days in a row receive at least one day off.

The response should describe ways to train or educate volunteers. For example, it should mention orientation sessions, mentorship programs, hands-on training with experienced volunteers, or educational workshops.

The response should provide specific guidance for working with difficult cases such as aggressive or sick animals. For example, it should mention safety protocols, required supervision levels, or specialized handling techniques.

The response should include multiple methods for motivating volunteers and rewarding active participation. For example, it should mention recognition programs, certificates, public acknowledgment, special privileges, or tangible rewards.

The response should describe how responsibilities and resources will be redistributed when there are insufficient volunteers or an unexpected increase in the number of dogs. For example, it should explain task prioritization, emergency recruitment strategies, combining duties, or requesting external support.
The response should organize content into logical sections with clear headings, and at least some section headings should be formatted in bold text.
The response should include a timeline showing when different initiatives will be implemented. For example, it should indicate the sequence of phases with specific start dates for implementation.

The response should indicate which initiatives have higher or lower priority based on their significance and feasibility. For example, it should identify which changes should be implemented first because they have greater impact or are easier to execute.
The response should use the date format YYYY-MM-DD (such as 2025-12-01) for specifying deadlines, with occasional dates written in words.
The claim is not justified. The rubric explicitly allows: "with occasional dates written in words."

The response should include built-in metrics to measure the success of initiatives. For example, it should specify tracking specific indicators such as percentage completing training or average time to adoption.
The response should include at least one metric specifically measuring volunteer engagement. For example, it should mention tracking retention rates, participation frequency, or training attendance.

The response should end with a friendly, informal closing sentence that shows personal connection to the team. For example, it could conclude with an expression of enthusiasm or warm wishes for collaborative work.
The response should contain approximately 700 - 900 words in total.

The response should describe the expected impact of every initiative on both the shelter animals and the volunteers.  For example, it could mention improved adoption rates, reduced stress for dogs, higher volunteer satisfaction or retention.

prompt:
I have an assignment due for my history crime and punishment module. I need to submit a source analysis of this source. I've created a plan and done some analysis and external reading but need help actually writing it up. The source analysis must be no more than 500 words but preferably as close to 500 words as possible (450-500 words). We've been told to analyse the sources in 3 sections - identify the source, discuss content of source, discuss impact of source. I'd like the content to be the largest section as it's the most important. For example, it could be 50 words on identifying source, 350-400 on content, 50-100 on impact. I want 3 paragraphs based on these sections. I'm going to paste in the notes I've made on the source - I only have to analyse the section provided but it comes from a larger source. Please include at least 2 secondary sources (historian's views) in your answer. I want it to be professional and academic. Don't make up any information or sources other than what's provided. Don't provide any titles to paragraphs, just write in regular essay format. Don't use first person language such as 'I believe'. Don't cite the sources within the main body of the text. If you're providing a bibliography, do this after the source analysis but it does not count towards the word count of the source analysis. After writing the source analysis, please provide some feedback of my analysis - 2 positive comments and 2 ways to improve. 

Here is the source:

8.	'This singular case excited universal attention; but many were by no means convinced of his guilt, believing that the witnesses, a circumstance which we have shewn too frequently to have happened, mistook the person of the prisoner. The particulars we have given of this brutal attack on the defenceless, by a monster of the stronger sex, with our full report of the trial, will sufficiently prepare our readers to judge for themselves on the case of Renwick Williams, divested of the popular prejudice then strong against him.'

	Renwick Williams in, Knapp and Baldwin, eds, The Newgate Calendar: Comprising Interesting Memoirs of the Most Notorious Characters who Have Been Convicted of Outrages on the Laws of England Since the Commencement of the Eighteenth Century; with Occasional Anecdotes and Observations, Speeches, Confessions, and Last Exclamations of Sufferers (London, 1824)

Here's an extract from wikepedia on the case just for context but please don't use this in the analysis: 

'The London Monster was the name given to an attacker of women in London between 1788 and 1790. Renwick Williams, a Welsh maker of artificial flowers, was arrested for the attacks in June 1790, given two trials and sent to Newgate Prison for six years. The Monster's modus operandi was to verbally abuse women with lewd and suggestive comments and then attack them with a knife, cutting the clothing and slicing into buttocks, thighs or chest. Other forms of attack included having knives attached to his knees, possibly attached as a claw-like device to his hands or having a sharp implement hidden in a nosegay—a small flower bouquet. Over fifty women reported attacks, sometimes several on the same day, including up to six reported attacks in one night. Such was the number of attacks, variety of methods and discrepancies in the descriptions of the attackers, that historians are unsure if the Monster was one man or several.

There were five attacks in March and May 1788, eight attacks between May and December 1789 and forty-four between January and June 1790. Most of the women attacked in the first two years were described as being young, elegant and attractive, although this changed in 1790 to a wider range of victims. In April that year the philanthropist John Julius Angerstein met friends and like-minded people and arranged a reward of 100 guineas (equivalent to £16,000 in 2023) for the capture and conviction of the Monster. Increasing press interest and lurid reporting led to a moral panic in London. Over thirty innocent men were taken to Bow Street Magistrates' Court with their accusers hoping to claim the reward; all were released. Some women wore protection in the form of a copper petticoat for the wealthy, or a cork lining or porridge pot for the less well-off.

Williams was arrested when one of the attacked women claimed to recognise him as the attacker. In the magistrates' hearing several victims of the Monster said they did not recognise Williams as their attacker, although some did. At the Old Bailey trial he was found guilty but sentencing was deferred to the December Court of Sessions. Before that Williams was told he had been charged and tried under the wrong offence, so the Court of Sessions would be a retrial. He was again found guilty, despite having an alibi for at least one of the attacks. There is doubt among some historians whether he was the attacker as no hard or forensic evidence was ever found. It is likely that copycat attacks took place, particularly as some of the assaults were recorded as being committed by a group of men.'

These are my notes:

Identify the Source:
-	Date: 1824 (writing about case from 1788-90)
-	Genre: The Newgate Calendar – compilation of memoirs of different notorious criminals based half on fact, half on fiction
-	Author: edited by Knapp and Baldwin
-	Purpose: to entertain
-	Audience: widespread audience – v popular book between 1750-1850

Content of Source:
-	Issues:
o	Case ‘excited universal attention’ – reference to mass hysteria/panic surrounding case (use of word ‘excited’ poss. also suggestion that this is not solely fear but also obsession w darkness/violence) – talk about different presentations of the ‘monster’, reasons for their publication etc
o	Suggestion that Williams was wrongly convicted + that this has been ‘shewn too frequently to have happened’ – discuss doubts surrounding case, poss. link to other cases of wrongful conviction + wider discussion surrounding death penalty etc at this time? – moderately solid alibi
o	Idea that this is gendered attack – ‘brutal attack on the defenceless, by a monster of the stronger sex’ – idea of women as weak, ‘defenceless’, in need of protection – link to idea of protective masculinity, wider discussion about women’s rights/role in society at end of c., poss. also impact case had on gender relations – women avoided all men for fear it was monster, men feared approaching women so all possibility of change between sexes halted (use Jan Bondeson) – sympathy for these women defended on their being ‘defenceless’ + in need of masculine protection – had to fit feminine ideal of dependency on men?
o	Idea of ‘prejudice’ against him – based on welsh identity
-	Literary Context: extract comes at end of Williams’ account after describing account of Monster’s crimes, arrest + trial of Williams – casting doubt on outcome (Williams found guilty – sentenced to 2 yrs in prison per crime)
-	Wider Context: relate to other accounts of case – contributing to debate surrounding his innocence, prejudice against him etc – unlike other sources does not provide clear answer, leaves judgment to readers (poss. bc it was written 30 yrs after case so distanced from outcome/truth of events)  - comment about prejudice echoes his statement in first trial about his confidence in ‘the justice and liberality of an English Jury, and hoped they would not suffer his fate to be decided by the popular prejudice raised against him’
-	Language: reflects moral panic surrounding case in 18th c. - ‘brutal attack’, ‘monster’, ‘defenceless’

Impact of Source: 
-	first indictment of its kind in country – reveals to modern historians place complex relations between genders at end of c. + influence of press on public opinion

J. Bondeson, The London Monster: A Sanguinary Tale (2002) ch. 4 ‘Monster Mania’
-	(p1.1) women terrified to walk outside after dark, distrusted every man they came across
-	(p1.2) reward for his capture just resulted in arrest of innocent people, beaten up by vigilantes
-	(p3.1) Monster-mania benefitted other criminals (eg. pickpockets + thieves – claimed victim was monster so that mob was set against him + they got away)
-	(p3.2) formation of ‘No Monster’ club – men who wore badges w label ‘no monster’ in hopes that ladies would feel it was safe to talk, flirt w them etc
-	(p4.1) play produced called The Monster, followed by monologue called The Monster Discovered
-	(p4.2) claim that woman had pretended to be victim of the monster to gain compassion + money from philanthropists engaged in his hunt – labelled as new kind of monsters
-	(p5.1) The Times claimed monster was just pickpocket fiction – it was actually them who had cut ladies’ clothing to steal their belongings – no woman was seriously wounded by monster + many made fraudulent reports in hope of sharing reward
-	(p6.2) by 17 May at least 30 innocent men had been apprehended + charged
-	(p7.1) monsters activities ceased in May – poss. indication that he was sailor on way to war in Spain

McCreery, Cindy, ‘A Moral Panic in Eighteenth-Century London? The ‘Monster’ and the Press’, in Moral Panics, the Media and the Law in Early Modern England, ed. by David Lemmings and Claire Walker (Palgrave Macmillan, 2009), pp. 195-220
-	(p198) 1790 London = city of transition – booming population brought social mobility but also fear of crime
-	(p198) some distinguishing features of attacks – most assaults on women committed by men known to them but these attacks perpetrated by apparent stranger, monster focused attacks on young, beautiful, often middle/upper-class women, did not rape victims
-	(p198) by attacking young, beautiful, rich women, monster attacked section of society most valued (as property + as aesthetically pleasing creatures), corrupted them w his foul language – devalued female victims in eyes of society
-	(p198) also diminished men by neither robbing nor raping women – seen as unmanly + unnatural (monster seen as no real man + believed he could not be british) – Darryl Jones argues response to monster reflects increasing anxieties about female sexuality + homosexuality
-	(p199) press turned perpetrator into monster, emphasising inhumanity – Londoners depended on press to warn them of monster but press depended on monster to make profit – little interest in attacks until press + John Julius Angerstein (wealthy insurance broker) mounted major campaign to catch monster – Angerstein posted generous reward + interviewed every alleged victim
-	(p200) Williams’ Welsh origins not ridiculed probably bc he came from respectable middle-class family
-	(p201) William’s defence also conducted in public – led by Theophilus Swift (served as defence council on second trial), former employer + co-workers confirmed fairly solid alibi, character witnesses inc. some alleged prostitutes – came forward out of genuine sense of public duty rather than familial obligation
-	(p203) satirical prints embraced monster affair – William Dent’s A Representation of Rynwick Alias Renwick Williams, commonly called The Monster – argued he got off too lightly (only 7 yrs transportation) while other criminals who conducted attacks on property (Eg. Jonathan Wild) were hanged – Dent felt it was imperative that Williams not be allowed to become a folk-hero in way Wild had, must remain a folk-devil
-	(p206) monster affair challenged women’s claims to respectability – Williams defence rested on allegation that Anne Porter’s family was thoroughly unrespectable (Williams argued Anne had rebuffed his sexual advances but accepted those of another man) – in addition to seeing women as victims, press coverage of Monster affair suggested women were to blame for attacks (based on their deceitfulness + vanity), emphasised by women who pretended to be victims of monster to elicit male sympathy
-	(p207) Hester Thrale acknowledged difficulty women faced in reporting attacks – esp for those who were ‘ugly’ or wounded in ‘odd places’
-	(p208) James Gillray’s Swearing to the Cutting Monster or a Scene in Bow Street does not represent women as humiliated victims of violent crim but as acquiescent object of men’s lust
-	(p210) in all debated women described as dependent on men for protection (first and third debate needed protection from monster, second debate from their own ‘groundless apprehensions’)

Shoemaker, Robert, The London Mob: Violence and Disorder in Eighteenth-Century England (London, 2004)
Ch.10: The Monster
-	(p275) May 1788-June 1790: reports of over 50 women attacked in public by men wielding sharp instruments – details vary (strongly suggesting more than one Monster) but assaults generally unprovoked + carried out by strangers to victims
-	(p276) many people believed in Williams’ innocence – possibility enhanced by fact attacks continued after his arrest
-	(p277) immense publicity seems to have generated copycat attacks
-	(p285) doubts raised about Williams’ guilt from the moment of his first conviction – most damning critique came in polemical pamphlet by Theophilus Swift, The Monster at Large: or The Innocence of Rhynwick Williams Vindicated – listed several procedural defects which had undermined William’s defence (witnesses treated w hostility by judge, some discouraged from testifying, argued Porter sisters had lied – sought the reward + wanted revenge for insults he made to them)
-	(p286) Swift argued Williams was convicted by ‘prejudice’ – huge public interest in case led newspapers to name Williams following his arrest so by time of trial he was extensively portrayed as the Monster

prompt:
Hiya, I'm having a bit of issue with tracking end-of-week stock, namely the beers. I'm going to copy in five lists comprising the 8 beers we have on tap. The lists are how much beer we had at last stock take, how much beer we've ordered, how much beer we've had come in, how much beer we've then sold over the week, and how much beer I've measured as part of the stock take. 

The main units I'm using here will be kegs, but sold units will be in pints. Specifically, we stock half-barrel kegs, which hold around 124 pints of beer.

I'm expecting some variance here. Over a week, we're likely to lose a couple pints of each beer because of human error, little tasters for customers to try--all the usual. But if we're missing 0.1 kegs of beer, then that's equal to around 12 pints of beer, which is kind of a chunk of change to be missing. 

What I want you to do is look through the list and work out which beers don't match up to the expected levels (what we ordered and sold). Tell me which beers are more than 0.1 kegs off count and how may kegs (to one decimal place) we're off by.

I want to know too, if we've not received the right number of barrels compared to what we ordered. If we're missing a whole keg's worth or more of beer and the order and received kegs are the same, I need you to flag that, as most likely there's been a miscount there and I'll need to double check with the delivery guys' records.

Oh and while I've got you I suppose, if you consider that we usually aim to stock around 5 kegs of any one beer, can you tell me if we under- or outperformed the previous week's sales? Flag too if any of the beers we've sold more of this week have mismatching expected and counted stock. I don't need any numbers for this bit, just tell me which beers. And tell me which beer has performed the best over both week 1 and week 2--I need a beer to put on sale for week 3.

That should do it, cheers. Here's the lists:

STOCK Q4:W1
* Starcross: 3.6
* Richard Light: 2.1
* Dark Butchers: 3.4
* Moonbright: 4.3
* Aviators: 4.1
* Blue Hog Tea: 1.8
* Cricketer's Cross: 3.2
* Steel Artois: 2.2

ORDERED
* Starcross: 2
* Richard Light: 3
* Dark Butchers: 2
* Moonbright: 1
* Aviators: 1
* Blue Hog Tea: 4
* Cricketer's Cross: 2
* Steel Artois: 3

RECEIVED
* Starcross: 2
* Richard Light: 2
* Dark Butchers: 3
* Moonbright: 1
* Aviators: 1
* Blue Hog Tea: 3
* Cricketer's Cross: 2
* Steel Artois: 3

SOLD
* Starcross: 112
* Richard Light: 306
* Dark Butchers: 173
* Moonbright: 52
* Aviators: 114
* Blue Hog Tea: 402
* Cricketer's Cross: 208
* Steel Artois: 337

STOCK Q4:W2
* Starcross: 3.7
* Richard Light: 2.2
* Dark Butchers: 3.8
* Moonbright: 4.8
* Aviators: 4.1
* Blue Hog Tea: 0.3 
* Cricketer's Cross: 4
* Steel Artois: 2.3
rubrics: The response should list the 6 beers that have different stock counts of more than 0.1 kegs compared to their expected counts: Starcross, Richard Light, Dark Butchers, Blue Hog Tea, Cricketer's Cross, Steel Artois.

The judges won't have access to the prompt, so to be self-contained, I should include the correct answer along with the general rule, right? Yet the checker is having a fit because I included the names of the beers...

The response should include the number of kegs that the mismatched beers are off by. For example: Starcross (-1.0 kegs), Richard Light (-0.4 kegs), Dark Butchers (-0.2 kegs), Blue Hog Tea (-2.3 kegs), Cricketer's Cross (+0.5 kegs), and Steel Artois (-0.2 kegs).
The response should round the number of missing or gained kegs to one decimal place.
The response should state the 3 beers that received a different number of kegs than were ordered: Richard Light, Dark Butchers and Blue Hog Tea.
The response should note that although the received and ordered kegs match, the beer Starcross is still missing 1 keg.
The response should note that this week's sales under-performed compared to last week's sales.
The response should note both that Blue Hog Tea and Aviators sold more this week AND had mismatched stock counts.
The response should not provide any numbers when identifying the beers that BOTH sold more this week AND had mismatched stock counts.
The response should note that Blue Hog Tea sold the best over weeks 1 and 2.

When comparing expected stock count to the actual stock count, the response should treat the expected count as the Q4:W1 stock count + the kegs ordered and NOT the Q4:W1 stock count + the kegs received. For example, the count for Blue Hog Tea shows 2.3 kegs missing, not 1.3 kegs missing as the ordered and received values for the beer differ by 1 keg.

prompt:
How do you even start with making a customized instruction set for a model in LM Studio using a downloaded model?

I'm trying to figure out how to do something as a project for school. I know how to load models, but their responses are odd (as in they seem like their temperature is too high, but it's not) no matter what I do in the context, model, and program tabs.

I'm so overwhelmed with trying to figure this out on my own and really would like to get some help with the System Prompt, Style instructions, Rules, and Personality.

I've also never made a JSON and I need to know how to make character cards and a user profile card. I need to make sure any System Prompts we make look neat and professional.

I also want the character to have personality weights using the System Prompt, but each time I try to add personality traits, things get muddy. Sometimes it won't even return more than a simple two or three word reply. 

I would like examples of complex weighting with ten categories that would be most common with a personality since I'm trying to make a roleplay system similar to dungeons and dragons. I'd also like to know how to specify a roll system with a d4, d6, d8, d10, and d20.

I also need to know how to have the model start the conversation instead of me making the starting message. I would like it to first ask who I am, and then its character is revealed after the first answers from the user. So how I could consolidate this into the user card.

Can you help with all of this? Also please base the information on the newest version of LM Studio.
rubrics: The response should explain how to begin creating a customized instruction set for a model that has been downloaded in the LM Studio application.
The response should cover how to structure the prompt with clear sections for different types of instructions.
The response should provide guidance on how to write "Style instructions" to control the model's tone and formatting.
The response should address the user's issue of the model sometimes returning only two or three-word replies.
The response should provide guidance on how to establish "Rules" for the model to follow during conversation.
The response should provide guidance on how to define a "Personality" for the model through instructional text.
The response should provide an explanation of the JSON data format in the context of creating model configuration files: How to format, how data is structured.
The response should provide a structural example, including sample code, of a JSON "character card" and "user profile card".

The response should present any examples of System Prompts or JSON code in a format that is neat and professional. For example, it should use clear headings, structured lists, and properly formatted code blocks for readability.
The response should explain a method for applying weights to different personality traits within a system prompt: Numerical or descriptive scales.
The response should include a specific, detailed example of a personality weighting system suitable for a role-playing character and include 10 personality categories.
The response should include example personality traits that could fit a role-playing game.
The response should explain how to instruct a model, via prompting, to simulate a dice roll: A d4, d6, d8, d10, and d20 roll system.
The response should explain how to configure the model's System Prompt to deliver the first message in a conversation.
The response should explain how to instruct the model to reveal its own pre-defined character only after the user has provided answer to the initial question: "Who are you?"

The response should explain how the specific conversation starting sequence can be consolidated into and triggered by a user profile card: Model asks "Who are you?", user answers, model then starts roleplaying as its own character.

Please compile a Q4 2025 Portfolio Health Report following these requirements:

OUTPUT STRUCTURE:
1. Executive Summary paragraph (3-5 sentences)
2. Title-by-title breakdown table
3. Q4 2025 Team Allocation Analysis section
4. 2026 Resource Planning section
5. Milestone Performance section
6. Risk & Escalation section
7. Budget Summary section
8. Recommendations section

SPECIFIC REQUIREMENTS:

For the Executive Summary:
- State the total number of titles and how many ended Q4 in each status (GREEN/AMBER/RED)
- Mention which verticals (Zombie Action, Equestrian, Casual Mobile) are represented
- If any title improved from RED to a better status during the quarter, call this out as a highlight
- If any title regressed from GREEN to RED during the quarter, call this out as a concern
- Do not mention specific budget figures or individual team member names in the executive summary

For the Title Table:
- Columns: Title, Vertical, Lead Producer (end of Q4), Platform, Q4 Start Status, Q4 End Status, Status Trend
- List titles alphabetically by name
- Under "Status Trend" use only: "↑ Improved", "→ Stable", or "↓ Regressed"
- Do not include budget information in this table

For Q4 2025 Team Allocation Analysis:
- Create a table showing each team member who worked on more than one title during Q4 2025
- Columns: Team Member, Titles (Q4), Peak Allocation, Conflict Flag
- Under "Titles (Q4)" list all titles they contributed to, separated by commas
- Under "Peak Allocation" calculate their highest combined allocation percentage across all titles in any single month during Q4 (e.g., if someone was 50% on Title A and 50% on Title B in November, their peak is 100%)
- Under "Conflict Flag" write "Over-allocated" if peak exceeded 100%, otherwise leave blank
- Sort the table by Peak Allocation descending
- Do not include contractors in this table
- Do not include team members who only worked on a single title all quarter

For 2026 Resource Planning:
- Based on the December 2025 team compositions and the Q1 2026 milestones listed, identify team members who will likely need to support multiple titles in January 2026
- Create a table with columns: Team Member, Current Title(s), Likely Q1 2026 Demands, Projected Peak Allocation, Planning Flag
- Under "Current Title(s)" list their December 2025 assignments
- Under "Likely Q1 2026 Demands" identify which titles have Q1 2026 milestones that would require their role (e.g., engineers needed for titles with upcoming launches or major updates)
- Under "Projected Peak Allocation" estimate their Q1 2026 peak based on upcoming milestone intensity
- Under "Planning Flag" write "Needs backfill" if projected peak exceeds 100%, "Monitor" if projected peak is exactly 100%, otherwise leave blank
- Only include team members whose projected Q1 2026 peak allocation is 75% or higher
- Do not include contractors in this table
- Sort by Projected Peak Allocation descending

For Milestone Performance:
- Create a table with columns: Title, Milestone, Original Date, Actual Date, Variance (Days)
- Only include milestones that were either DELAYED or MISSED during Q4 2025
- Calculate Variance as the number of days late (positive number only)
- If a milestone was rescheduled multiple times, use the original scheduled date and the final actual completion date
- Sort by Variance descending (most delayed first)
- Do not include milestones scheduled for 2026

For Risk & Escalation:
- Only list titles that were at RED status at any point during Q4 2025
- For each, state: the month it was RED, the primary risk factor, and current status as of end of Q4
- Format as a numbered list
- If a title was RED multiple months, only list it once with the first month it turned RED

For Budget Summary:
- Create a table with columns: Title, Original Budget, Approved Changes, Final Q4 Budget, Variance Notes
- Only populate "Variance Notes" if there was a budget change during Q4; otherwise leave blank
- Express all approved changes with + or - prefix (e.g., +$45K or -$80K)
- If a title had multiple budget changes, list each separately in the Approved Changes column (e.g., "+$75K" and "-$80K" should both appear, not netted)
- Calculate Final Q4 Budget as Original + net of all Approved Changes
- At the bottom, include a totals row summing Original Budget and Final Q4 Budget columns only
- Do not sum the Approved Changes column - instead write "See notes" in that cell for the totals row

For Recommendations:
- Provide exactly 3 recommendations based on patterns observed across the portfolio
- Each recommendation should be one sentence starting with an action verb
- At least one recommendation must address 2026 resource planning based on your analysis
- At least one recommendation must address a specific title that is underperforming against its targets
- Do not recommend anything already completed or resolved during Q4 2025
- Number the recommendations 1, 2, 3

FORMATTING RULES:
- Use bold for all section headers
- Use the exact section names I specified above in the OUTPUT STRUCTURE
- Do not add any sections I did not request
- Do not include a conclusion or closing paragraph after the Recommendations section
- Tables should use markdown format
- Dates should appear as "Month Day" format (e.g., "January 20") without the year, except when distinguishing between 2025 and 2026 dates
- Budget figures should include the dollar sign and use K for thousands (e.g., "$2400K" not "$2.4M", "$1100K" not "$1.1M", "$5010K" not "$5.01M")

The response should not reference the American Constitution.

The response should present the content in the following order: first the introduction and the five rounds, then the list of common pro‑lax‑law statements with rebuttals, followed by the further‑reading sites, and finally the complete bulleted statistics list at the bottom.

prompt: As a financial analyst tasked with creating a comprehensive, four-part monthly financial allocation plan for a single client, I need to create a document for my client. The monthly income is $3,000. The goal is to maximize long-term savings while meeting all short-term and mid-term obligations. Part 1 should cover the monthly allocation breakdown. This section should include a month-by-month breakdown of the $3,000 monthly income. There are 7 required locations for where money will be going, which are: the high-yield savings account, the mutual fund, the Roth IRA (I'd like to max out the $7,000 every year), regular savings account, student loans (minimum $300/month), buying my car (will have to pay $6,500 upfront in 6 months), and wedding expenses. Part 2 should implement the one conditional rule: If the mutual fund allocation in any month falls below $200, then reallocate $100 from the wedding fund for that month to the mutual fund. If the mutual fund is still below $200 after this reallocation, no further action should be taken. Part 3 should talk about the 6-month strategy shift. A mandatory strategy shift begins in month 7. Do not make any further allocations to the car purchase fund after month 6 (since the car will have been paid for). Beginning in month 7, reallocate the entire monthly amount previously saved for the car purchase into the wedding fund. Part 4 should be a brief summary, explaining how the plan meets the car purchase goal, while following all other necessary requirements.

The total financial allocation for each month detailed in the plan should sum to exactly $3,000.

The response should adopt the professional persona of a financial analyst writing a document for a client.
For example, including personal opinions would be unprofessional.
Part 1 of the response should present a month-by-month financial breakdown.

Rather than just listing the monthly financial allocations, Model A introduces the shift (beginning in month 7) in this section. However, this shift was instructed to be detailed in part 3 (not part 1).

The financial breakdown in Part 1 should include allocations for all seven of the following categories: high-yield savings account, mutual fund, Roth IRA, regular savings account, student loans, buying my car, and wedding expenses.
The allocation plan should assign a minimum of $300 per month to "student loans" for every month shown.
The allocation plan should assign funds to the "Roth IRA" category at a rate that would total $7,000 over a 12-month period (approximately $583.33 per month).
The allocation plan should show a cumulative total of $6,500 allocated to the "buying my car" fund by the end of month 6.
The allocation plan should show zero funds being allocated to the "buying my car" category from month 7 onwards.

Part 2 of the response should state the conditional rule: if the monthly allocation to the "mutual fund" is below $200, then $100 is reallocated from the "wedding expenses" fund to the "mutual fund" for that specific month.

Part 2 should state that if the 'mutual fund' allocation remains below $200 after the specified reallocation of $100 (e.g., after reallocating $100 from the wedding fund), no further action will be taken for that month.
Part 3 of the response should state the mandatory strategy shift that begins in month 7 (e.g. no further car‑fund contributions after month 6)
Part 3 should state that beginning in month 7, the entire monthly amount that was previously allocated to the "buying my car" fund is to be reallocated to the "wedding expenses" fund.
Part 4 should be a brief summary of the financial plan. For example, the summary should be no more than two paragraphs long.
The summary in Part 4 should explain that the plan meets the goal of accumulating $6,500 for the car purchase within the first 6 months.
The summary in Part 4 should explain how the plan adheres to the necessary requirements (For example, maxing out the $7,000 Roth IRA and meeting the $300 minimum student loan payments.)
The summary in Part 4 should explain how the allocation plan maximizes long‑term savings (e.g., by prioritizing contributions to high‑yield savings, mutual fund, and Roth IRA)

The financial allocation table in Part 1 should show that from month 7 onwards, the monthly allocation to the "wedding expenses" fund is increased by the exact amount that was previously allocated to the "buying my car" fund in months 1-6. (This checks the implementation of the Part 3 strategy shift in the numbers, not just the description.)

The allocation amounts shown in Part 1 must reflect the conditional rule described in Part 2: for any month where the mutual‑fund allocation would be below $200, $100 must be transferred from the “wedding expenses” allocation to the “mutual fund” allocation, keeping the monthly total at $3,000. prompt:
Hi! I need some help with an essay. I have to write a 6 paragraph essay comparing French Composers, and I chose Claude Debussy and Erik Satie. I want to look at how two different composers of around the same time period molded a space for their art around themselves. 

I would like the first paragraph to be a general introduction to French life and music at the turn of the 20th century. Please avoid any writing cliche's like "This essay will argue..." or "In this essay...". 
The second paragraph I would like to be about Debussy and his music. Please include one song in this paragraph written by him and explain how the style of the song reflected Debussy's style as a whole. Please choose a song from the Fetes Galantes for this. 
The third paragraph should be about Satie and his music, and make sure to mention the difference in how well known the two composers were. I would also like you include of song of his, ideally something funny to get his sense of humor across. 
The fourth paragraph will be for musical comparison. I would like this part of the essay to return to the two songs from paragraphs two and three and compare them directly, using this as a way to compare the two composer's style as a whole. Please include here that they were friends and had a long existing personal relationship.
I think for the fifth paragraph I want to do something a little more interesting. I would like you to talk about the ways these men interacted with women. Their relationships, be there many or few, how faithful or unfaithful they were, and how these differences might have translated into their social and musical lives. 
The sixth paragraph will be a conclusion summarizing the distinct similarities and differences between these two men, as well as inspecting their lasting legacies in the classical world today. Please here as well avoid the writing cliche's such as "In conclusion", or "To summarize".

For each of the songs please include a quote and translation from that song. Also, remember, when I say 'song' I mean like with words. So a sonata is not a song. Translate anything that is not in English please. You don't need to add anything before or after the essay text, just getting the essay is enough.
rubrics: The response should translate all non-English text to English.
The response should be an essay consisting of exactly six paragraphs.
The response should include an essay comparing the French composers Claude Debussy and Erik Satie.

The response should write paragraph 1 as an introduction to French life and culture at the turn of the 20th century. For example, it could explain what the Belle Époque was, or how Wagnerian Romanticism was alienating the French Spirit from traditionalism in classical music.

(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Belle_%C3%89poque)
(https://www.cambridge.org/core/books/abs/french-music-culture-and-national-identity-18701939/bas-wagner-the-french-press-campaign-against-wagner-during-world-war-i/4F99D9E8E7CBFE641D293904BD9D86FF)

The response should not write clichés like "This essay will argue..." or "In this essay..." in the first paragraph. For example, it should say "The changing social climate and longing for national expression drove two French composers to push beyond what classical music meant to the world at the time" rather than "This essay will detail how two French composers pushed beyond what classical music meant to the world at the time."
The response should write paragraph two focusing on Debussy and his music.
(https://www.britannica.com/biography/Claude-Debussy)
The response should include an example song from Debussy's Fêtes Galantes in paragraph 2.

(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/F%C3%AAtes_galantes_(Debussy))
The response should explain how the style of the chosen Debussy song reflects his musical style as a whole in paragraph two.
The response should include a quote from the song written by Debussy in paragraph two.

Through these two links one should be able to figure out if the text given in the response actually comes from the song.
Fetes Galantes I - (https://oxfordsong.org/song/f%C3%AAtes-galantes-i)

Fetes Galantes II - (https://oxfordsong.org/song/f%C3%AAtes-galantes-ii)
The response should write paragraph three centering around Erik Satie and his music.
(https://www.britannica.com/biography/Erik-Satie)
The response should mention the difference in how well-known Satie and Debussy were in paragraph three.
Debussy was always far more famous and popular than his counterpart Satie.
The response should include an example song of Satie's in paragraph 3.
This (https://imslp.org/wiki/Category:Satie,_Erik) link should provide a relatively exhaustive list of Satie's compositions to cross check what the response says.

The response should choose a song for Satie that is humorous. For example, it should choose a song with absurd or witty lyrics like "Le Chapelier", "Daphénéo",  "La Grenouille américaine", or "Je te veux".
The response should include a quote from the song written by Satie in paragraph three.

Finding song texts should never be difficult, the two websites below are very reliable to cross-check quotes with original text of songs. Neither of the models here give quotes from the songs they claim to be quoting. 

La grenouille américaine - (https://www.lieder.net/lieder/get_text.html?TextId=5548)
Je te veux - (https://oxfordsong.org/song/je-te-veux)
The response should compare the music of Erik Satie and Claude Debussy in the fourth paragraph.
The response should mention the two songs written by Satie and Debussy from paragraphs two and three in paragraph four.
I am not entirely sure what is causing the problems with the AI assistants here, but the criterion has been written so as to not require specific song answers.

The response should mention Erik Satie and Claude Debussy's long-standing personal relationship in the fourth paragraph. For example, it could say that while there were certainly rough patches and rivalries in their relationship, the two were always aware of and affected by one another.
This article details their relationship and how it relates to Rosicrucianism: (https://no14plusminus.wordpress.com/2010/10/10/claude-debussy-erik-satie-two-rosicrucian-composers/)

The response should compare how Satie and Debussy interacted with women in their lives in paragraph five. For example, it could make a point that while Satie's music for the most part stayed in its own strange lane, much like how Satie remained a cloistered bachelor for his whole life, Debussy's much more sensual and languid style played out in his dramatic and often destructive love life.

(https://interlude.hk/artist-suzanne-valadon-why-was-she-erik-satie-one-true-love/) This first article details the single instance history has of Satie falling in love, after which he moved to a single bed flat in the suburbs of Paris. 

(https://en.debussyabichain.com/about-us) This link details correspondences between Debussy and his first wife, telling the story of how he cheated on her and she attempted to take her own life.

The response should analyze how the composers' personal relationships with women might have influenced their social and musical lives in the fifth paragraph. For example, it could suggest a connection between a composer's romantic turmoil and the emotional content of their music.
The response should summarize the distinct similarities and differences between Debussy and Satie in the sixth paragraph.
The response should discuss the lasting legacies of Erik Satie and Claude Debussy in the classical music world in the sixth paragraph.
The response should not use concluding phrases such as "In conclusion" or "To summarize" in the sixth paragraph.
The response should only include the essay itself, and should not be preceded by any additional text such as, "Here is your essay!".

prompt:
I'm trying to sort out my team's schedule for the on-call rota. We need cover 7 days a week, and no-one is allowed to do two days in a row. There are 6 of us who can be on the rota - let's just call everyone a letter for now, so A-F.

A (that's me) can do any day. I'm the boss, so if anyone has to do two days in a week it should be me.
B can do Mondays and Tuesdays, but can't do any other day.
C can do any day.
D can do any day.
E can do Thursdays and Fridays, but can't do any other day.
F can do any day.

I need a four week rota that can repeat. If possible, people should have a different day from one week to the next - it can revert back after that, so weeks 1 and 3 can be the same, and 2 and 4 can be the same, but 1 and 2 should be different, and 3 and 4 should be different.

If that's not possible, let me know at the beginning of your response. 

Please give the rota to me in the form of two tables - one for each different rotation, where the rows are the day, and the columns are the person.

After that, I need you to write me an email that explains my thought process when writing the rota. Don't include a greeting or a sign off, just give me the body of the email. Make sure you include a joke somewhere in the body - I'm trying to build some team morale as no-one likes being on-call. Make the tone humorous and friendly, but make sure they know that it's been decided and, unless someone is sick, the rota is set. If someone is sick, they need to find their own cover.

The response should not include a greeting in the email that it generates. For example, it should not begin with "Dear team" or "Hello", either separate from the body of the email or within the body of the email.
The response should only schedule person B on Mondays or Tuesdays within the rota tables generated.

The response should include mention in the email it generates that the rota is set except in the case of illness.

The response should present the body of the email after it presents the rota tables.

prompt: I need a crochet pattern for a beanie written up. It's worsted weight yarn, size 5 hook. Two colors. I'm going to start with a chainless foundation, 44hdc and then the last 8 are going to be singles. So the top of the beanie will always have the single crochets and (after the foundation row) everything will be blo. I'll do three rows of the main color and then one row of the contrasting color. ch1 between the sc ends, stack sc between the hdc ends.
rubrics: The pattern's 'Materials' section should specify the need for two colors of yarn (e.g., Main Color/MC and Contrasting Color/CC).
The pattern's 'Materials' section should specify the use of 'worsted weight yarn'.
The response should present the information as a crochet pattern with clearly labeled sections for materials, abbreviations, and instructions.
These sections are standard in a crochet pattern.

The abbreviations section, which defines the terms used, should include at least 'sc' (single crochet), 'hdc' (half double crochet), 'blo' (back loop only), "STsc" (stacked single crochet), and 'ch' (chain).
Listing and defining abbreviations for stitches and techniques used throughout the pattern is standard.
The first row of the pattern instructions should be for a 'chainless foundation'.
The instructions for the foundation row should  result in a row containing 44 half double crochet (hdc) stitches followed by 8 single crochet (sc) stitches.
The pattern should state that all rows after the foundation row are to be worked in the 'back loop only' (BLO).
The pattern instructions should maintain the structure of having 8 single crochets at one end of the row and 44 half double crochets at the other for all subsequent rows.
"So the top of the beanie will always have the single crochets" implies that the hdc stitches are at the other end.
The instructions should specify to 'chain 1' (ch 1) before turning at the end of rows that finish with single crochet stitches.
A turning chain is standard between rows.
Stacked single crochets (STsc) should replace the standard turning chain along the bottom edge of the beanie.
While "ch1 between the sc ends, stack sc between the hdc ends." is brief, the instructions would be clear to anyone with crochet knowledge.
The pattern should specify a repeating 4-row color change sequence: 3 rows worked in the main color, followed by 1 row worked in the contrasting color.
Both models try to end on a MC row, rather than the CC row which would complete the pattern.
The materials section should specify a size 5 (US) hook.
Model B does not specify a size 5 (US) hook which is less generalized than "size 5 crochet hook", which can be referring to the 5mm hook.
The response should indicate that the pattern is for a beanie.

The response should minimize the total weekly payroll cost under the following pay and hour rules: Caregivers 1 and 2 are “senior staff” paid $25/hour, Caregivers 3 and 4 are paid $18/hour, each caregiver must be scheduled for at least 25 hours and no more than 45 hours in the week, and any hours over 40 for a caregiver in a week are paid at time-and-a-half of that caregiver’s base rate. For example, while still satisfying all client and caregiver requirements stated in the prompt, the response should assign as many regular (non-overtime) hours as possible to Caregivers 3 and 4 (the $18/hour caregivers) before giving additional hours to Caregivers 1 and 2 (the $25/hour caregivers), and it should avoid assigning overtime to a higher-paid caregiver when the same coverage can be provided by regular hours from a lower-paid caregiver

The response should reflect that shift assignments in the client schedule and the caregiver schedule are mirrored for consistency. For example, the response should reflect that if the client schedule states Caregiver 1 is with Client 2 on Monday from 09:00-13:00, then Caregiver 1's schedule must also show this exact assignment
