prompt:
I have been tasked with creating an on-boarding program for my warehouse job. 

At first, I thought it would be just a few teaching a few things, such as how to properly lift furniture (I work at an online furniture retailer), but they want so much more than that. They want a weeklong training program essentially. I have most of the basic requirements: breaks, lifting, scanning, onboarding, etc. Could you help me create a schedule for that? 

I'll note that the company is open Mon-Fri, so each of those days should be present. Also, the timing is 6:00 to 2:30 (with a lunch at 10-10:30). Breaks are 15 minutes and they are around 8 and 12. This doesn't have to be exact but lunch should be.

Monday: Needs to cover onboarding - signing waivers, all that paperwork, as well as emergency contact, photo for ID badge, etc. (If you can think of anything else, please put it down, and I can clear it or not). A tour is probably going to happen before they are hired, but you can put that here anyway.

Tuesday:  If someone has prior Equipment Operating experience (denoted by EO), this day will be special for them, as we will go over SOP for that. Charging station tour, how to use, sign out sheet (this must be done before a piece of equipment is used). They will need to be evaluated/taught how to use the equipment. For not EO's, they will be shown how to use a hand truck/dolly and/or pallet jacks whatever you want to call it. This includes safety, using gloves, asking for help if the item is heavy, etc. Transporting items will need to be done safely as well as securely. Employee safety is a priority, but we do not want damaged good either. If this seems like a good place to teach proper lifting technique, then put that training here. 

Wednesday: This day will be dedicated to lifting/stacking materials in trucks. Each door bay has a light, fan, and stairs to help with lifting items and placing them above others. Explain safety for all of that. After this is shown properly, make sure each person demonstrates a proper lifting (also do this for Tuesday too). 

Thursday: SCANNING! Scanning is a huge part of our warehouse. Things are constantly getting miss scanned. Explain that there is a receiving function, placing/staging function (this can be in front of a door or in an aisle), and then a door function (when a product is actually inside a truck). Improper scanning can lead to discipline including write ups, and eventually dismissal if constant errors are made. this needs to be made clear. To pick something up, a worker will scan the PO (purchase order), and now it is on their forks. They will either then place the item in front of a door, placing it in a logical place or inside the truck. Stacking must be done efficiently and safely. 

Friday: Discuss UPH (units per hour). The warehouse expectation is 13 units an hour. This is very doable with the size of our warehouse. We will also need to go over typing up, straps, or load bars. These must be used when items are not secured or at the end of a truck. Each person must demonstrate proper use of these items. 

Is there anything else I need to include? If there is something you think I should add, please insert it inside brackets. Please make each day a heading. Also, bold all of the items to go over. Lifting, scanning, etc. Do not mention insurance. Also, do not include any metaphors or language that is not exact/concrete. Please word everything as simple as possible. 


Our new onboards are 

Employee 1
Employee 12
Employee 15
Employee 6
Employee 23

EO 2
EO 4
EO 9

Please mark who should be at each training. If there is more Employees than EO's give examples of one of them properly lifting, clocking in, stacking product, etc. (1 per section). 

Each onboarding process will be unique, so please make this one unique to the new onboards.

Oh lastly, please add clocking in/out as well as box repair (we have special tape for it).
rubrics: The response should create a weeklong schedule for Monday through Friday.
The response should schedule in 15-minute breaks around 8 and 12.
Response B does not always address breaks. It is inconsistent with how it mentions breaks.
The response should schedule lunch as 10 to 10:30.
While the response does give space from 10-10:30 each day, it does not always mention what this time is.
The response should schedule the following items on Monday: onboarding, signing waivers, emergency contact, photo for ID Badge, and a possible tour.
The response should schedule the following items for Equipment Operators (EO) on Tuesday: SOPs, charging station tour, how to use equipment, sign out sheet, and equipment evaluation.

The response should schedule the following items for Employees on Tuesday: hand truck/dolly operation, pallet jack operation, glove use, asking help for heavy items, and transporting items safely and securely.
The response should schedule proper lifting technique on Tuesday for both EOs and Employees.
The response should schedule the following items on Wednesday: lifting/stacking items into trucks, proper use of lights/fans/stairs, safety measures, and demonstration of proper lifting.

The response should schedule the following items on Thursday: proper scanning (receiving, staging/placing, door function), explain possible disciplinary actions of scanning errors (including write-ups and termination), how to scan a PO, placement of items (in front of door/inside), and efficient stacking.
Response A does not go over stacking at all.

The response should schedule the following items on Friday: Units Per Hour (UPH), warehouse expectation of 13 UPH, securing loads (load bars, tying up, straps), and demonstration of proper securing of a load.
Response B keeps the typo of "typing up" instead of "tying up". This is obviously a mistake, given the context.

The response should add anything that should be included in the schedule within brackets. For example, it could include securing a ramp, cleaning up at the end of the day, or use of PPEs (personal protective equipment).
The response should make each day a heading.
The response should bold all items that are being discussed. For example, it should bold scanning, lifting, etc.
The response should not mention insurance anywhere in the schedule.
The response should not use any metaphors or figurative language. For example, it should only word things in objective or concrete terms.
The response should use simple language. For example, it should not use flowery adjectives/adverbs to make it seem poetic.
The response should mark who of the employees (Employees 1, 12, 15, 6, 23) and/or EOs (EO 2, 4, 9) should be at each training session.

The response should be unique to this specific onboarding. For example, it should not state "all employees" without stating which of the new employees it is referring to to avoid confusion.

The response should add box repair to the schedule.

prompt: I am trying to understand snooker better. How do the scoring system and fouls work? I am familiar with pool using international rules, so use analogies to that game. I am a reasonable pool player - several break-and-runs every session. If I start now, how good could I become in a year? Would I be able to hit a 147? If not, tell me what I could reasonable expect to hit in a single break. Give me 5 players who I might not have heard of, say who retired before 2010, whose games I should study to improve my tactics and explain why you've chosen each one - definitely exclude any of the class of '92. Pick out a single frame for each of them that I can watch to learn more about their tactical play. Finally, give me a practice plan for the first 2 months. I can do 3 x 1.5hr sessions per week, to help transition me from pool to snooker. Show me specific solo drills and their purpose. If any of them relate to cue ball control, dedicate 15mins extra to those drills.
rubrics: The response should explain the scoring system in snooker, detailing the point values for each coloured ball (red=1, yellow=2, green=3, brown=4, blue=5, pink=6, black=7).
- Snooker scoring: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Snooker
The response should explain the rules for fouls in snooker. For example, it should mention that fouls award points to the opponent and list common fouls like potting the cue ball.

The response should use analogies to international pool rules when explaining the scoring and fouls in snooker. For example, it could compare potting the cue ball in snooker to a "scratch" in pool, or compare the requirement to pot a red then a colour to the sequence of potting a group of balls before the 8-ball.

The response should provide an estimate of how skilled a reasonable pool player could become at snooker in one year. For example, it might suggest they could develop a consistent potting ability and start building small breaks.
The response should state that hitting a 147 break is an unrealistic goal for the user within one year of starting.
The response should suggest reasonable highest break the user could expect to achieve in a single visit within a year. For example, a break in the range of 30-70 points.
- Difficult to assess objectively, as it depends on a lot of variables, but the point is that it would be well below 147.
The response should recommend exactly 5 snooker players for the user to study.
The response should not suggest players to study who retired from professional snooker during or after 2010. For example, Stephen Hendry, who retired in 2012, should be excluded.

The response should not recommend snooker players who are likely to be known by a typical pool player. For example, players that have won the World Championship such as Steve Davis or Ronnie O'Sullivan.
The response should not recommend any player from the Class of '92 (Mark Williams, Ronnie O'Sullivan, and John Higgins) as players to study.
The response should identify a single, specific frame of a match that the user can watch for each of the 5 recommended players.

The response should explain why the game of each of the five players it chooses is worth studying for tactical improvement. For example, it might highlight safety play, their break-building, or their attacking style.
The response should provide a practice plan that covers the first two months of training.
The response should not give a practice plan that is structured for anything other than three sessions per week.
The response should not provide practice sessions that are a length other than 90 minutes.

The response should provide a practice plan specifically designed to help a pool player transition to snooker. For example, it might include drills focusing on adjusting to potting on a larger table, and the different size/weight of the balls.
The response should give specific, detailed solo drills. For example, it could suggest a drill potting colours off their spots in reverse sequence, building up to a full colour clearance.
The response should explain the purpose of each drill it lists.
- Model B fails to explain the purpose of each drill explicitly.
The response should dedicate an extra 15 minutes to any drill that relates to cue ball control.

prompt:
I'm stuck and need help scheduling workers for the fast food shop I manage. 
Each worker gave me hours and days they were willing to work on, and I can easily find a solution. 
However corporate gave me some rather difficult requirements and I need help building an effective schedule.
First, every shift has a minimum amount of seniority (a score corporate defined to ensure effective staffing, everyone is given a score from 1-10). They need to have at least 20 seniority points each shift.
Every shift must have at least one trainee (denoted by a * by their name).
If a worker worked through a shift, they cannot work for another 10 hours to give them time to rest.
Staff have to work either 4, 6 or 8 hour long shifts.
There must be 4 staff members on at all times. They will shake on the upper-bound and there can be 5 staff members for at most 2 hours each day.

I also have my own values for staffing.
Each member of staff needs to get at least 3/4 of their desired number of hours, and at most 1.25x as many as their desired number of hours per week.
Staff must work only at times they agreed too, however if this is impossible, I want at most two staff who work one shift each out of their agreed times.


Here is the list of shifts I need to fill:
Monday:    8 :00AM - 10:00PM

Here is the list of workers I can use: (name - seniority, days, hours, desired-hours)

Nova* -     1,  Everyday,           8AM-6PM,    15
Bracken -   6,  M-Th,               10AM-5PM,   20
Moss -      4,  W-Sat,              9AM-8PM,    10
Flint* -    1,  (M,W,F,Sat,Sun),    8AM-10PM,   18

Slate* -    1,  Sat / Sun,          8AM-5PM,    8
Bramble -   7,  No weekends,        12PM-10PM,  20
Cinder -    2,  M-W,                12PM-10PM,  24
Fable* -    1,  Tu-Th,              8AM-10PM,   30
Koda -      4,  M-W,                10AM-10PM,  34
Quill -     8,  M-F,                8AM-10PM,   30
Rune -      4,  M-F,                8AM-10PM,   10
Vale -      3,  M-F,                8AM-10PM    20


In your response, give the intended schedule for each day as a list of employees in the order that they start their shifts. 
Make sure to include the start and end time of their shift in this list.
Please do not show how you got to that schedule. Only show the correct schedule.
After that write a mini report of what the schedule looks like, this should include the seniority level at every time an employee starts or ends their shift. It should also mention the hours of each employee and compare them with the desired hours of the employee. Make sure to write all the compromises you made. For example if you schedule someone when they wouldn't want to be available.

prompt:
I need my BDR team’s reporting for last week. I’ll give you a spreadsheet of their performance. What I need is for you to rank each BDR across dimensions, then calculate the top performers overall. I need rankings for: Stage 1 opportunities (S1), stage 2 opportunities (S2), stage 3 opportunities (S3), total calls, negative call rates, and email reply rates.

Provide the rankings in their own unique tables (ex one for S2 opportunities, one for S1s, etc.). Tables should be for rank, name, value, and points (in that order). Title each table BDR Team: (dimension), (week ending date). 

Each opportunity generates points based on the stage: 1 for 1 point, 2 for 3 points, and 3 for 5 points. The remainder generate points based on ranking: 1st gets 5 points, 2nd gets 4, 3rd gets 3, 4th gets 2, and 5th gets 1. Total calls and negative calls get double (1st gets 10, 2nd gets 8, etc). Provide a total score table as the first table with headers for Opportunities and Outreach (with each BDRs points).

The rankings are part of a weekly email sent to the BDR team. Before the tables, write a quick paragraph summary. The summary should congratulate and name the BDRs with the highest scores. There are also bonuses paid for the best performing BDR for opportunities ($75) and outreach ($30). This paragraph should also state the total S2s and S3s generated and how this compares to the targets (3 S3s and 5 S2s for each).

Opportunities should only be referred to as their short name (S1, S2, S3). All tables should be in descending from highest performing to lowest. Tables should appear from highest point values to lowest.

Week Ending Nov 22, 2025									
BDR	S1	S2	S3	Total Calls	Negative Calls	Negative Call Rate	Emails	Email Replies	Reply Rate
Joe	8	6	4	394	52	13.20%	97	1	1.03%
Tara	6	5	4	580	37	6.38%	127	3	2.36%
Carl	9	7	3	521	61	11.71%	158	3	1.90%
Bryan	10	5	2	585	72	12.31%	132	2	1.52%
Autumn	8	8	1	457	41	8.97%	102	3	2.94%
rubrics: The response should provide the tables in the order of highest point value to least (excluding the total score table): S3, S2, S1, total calls or negative calls (same points), and reply rates.
The response should only refer to opportunities by their short names: S1, S2, and S3. For example, it should not refer to them as stage 1 opportunities or S1 opportunities.

The response should calculate each BDR’s S2 opportunity scores as 3 points per opportunity. For example, the BDRs should have the following points: 18 for Joe, 15 for Tara, 21 for Carl, 15 for Bryan, and 24 for Autumn.

The response should calculate each BDR’s S1 opportunity scores as 1 point per opportunity. For example, the BDRs should have the following points: 8 for Joe, 6 for Tara, 9 for Carl, 10 for Bryan, and 8 for Autumn.
The response should title all tables in the format of BDR Team: (dimension), Nov 22, 2025.

The response should calculate the negative call rates based on rank (10 for 1st, 8 for 2nd, 6 for 3rd, 4 for 4th, and 2 for 5th). For example, the BDRs should have the following points: 2 for Joe, 10 for Tara, 6 for Carl, 4 for Bryan, and 8 for Autumn.

The response should calculate the email reply rates based on rank (5 for 1st, 4 for 2nd, 3 for 3rd, 2 for 4th, and 1 for 5th). For example, the BDRs should have the following points: 1 for Joe, 4 for Tara, 3 for Carl, 2 for Bryan, and 5 for Autumn.
The response should include a congratulatory statement for the BDR with the highest opportunity score in the summary (Joe).
The response should include a congratulatory statement for the BDR with the highest outreach score in the summary (Tara).
The response should mention the $75 bonus in the summary.
The response should mention the $30 bonus in the summary.
The response should state the total S2s generated in the summary (31).
The response should state the total S3s generated in the summary (14).
The response should compare the total BDR team's opportunity results to the target (3 S3s and 5 S2s for each BDR or 15 total S3s and 25 total S2s).

The response should order each table by the highest performing BDR to the lowest (descending order for all tables except for the negative call rates table, which should be in ascending order because lower values mean higher performance. For example, the total score table could use the opportunity score or a total score (if present).
The AI helper won't recognize that a lower negative call rate means a higher performance. The criterion is based on the prompt, requesting highest performing to lowest.

The response should include table headers for opportunities and outreach in the total score table.
The response should contain 7 tables for: S3, S2, S1, total calls, negative calls, email reply rates, and total scores.

The response should calculate the total calls based on rank (10 for 1st, 8 for 2nd, 6 for 3rd, 4 for 4th, and 2 for 5th). For example, the BDRs should have the following points: 2 for Joe, 8 for Tara, 6 for Carl, 10 for Bryan, and 4 for Autumn.

prompt:
I am trying to write a speech for the next city council meeting I am attending and I want to use the information in this text as the base. I am spacing out on what to write, however. Can you help? The speech is about Douglas firs and why we need better conservation. I want all of the reasoning to come solely from the text with the fourth section being the base for the opening paragraph. Focus solely on the Oregon and Washington-specific info, when applicable. Do not mention Canada or California. Do not utilize outside information. Have 5 paragraphs in total with a word count between 600-700. For my benefit, also include a single italicized sentence under each paragraph that begins with "Note:" that explains the reasoning of the info used. So I can freestyle if need be.


The Douglas fir (Pseudotsuga menziesii)[4] is an evergreen conifer species in the pine family, Pinaceae. It is the tallest tree in the Pinaceae family.[5] It is native to western North America and is also known as Douglas-fir,[6] Douglas spruce,[7] Oregon pine,[8] and Columbian pine.[9] There are three varieties: coast Douglas-fir (P. menziesii var. menziesii), Rocky Mountain Douglas-fir (P. menziesii var. glauca) and Mexican Douglas-fir (P. menziesii var. lindleyana).[10]

Despite its common names, it is not a true fir (genus Abies), spruce (genus Picea), or pine (genus Pinus). It is also not a hemlock (genus Tsuga); the genus name Pseudotsuga means "false hemlock".

DESCRIPTION
Douglas-firs are medium-sized to extremely large evergreen trees, 20–100 metres (70–330 feet) tall (although only coast Douglas-firs reach heights near 100 m)[11] and commonly reach 2.4 m (8 ft) in diameter,[12] although trees with diameters of almost 5 m (16 ft) exist.[13] The largest coast Douglas-firs regularly live over 500 years, with the oldest specimens living for over 1,300 years.[14] Rocky Mountain Douglas-firs, found further to the east,[15] are less long-lived, usually not exceeding 400 years in age.[16]

There are records of former coast Douglas-firs exceeding 120 m (390 ft)[17][18] in height, which if alive today would make it the tallest tree species on Earth. Particular historical specimens with heights exceeding 120 m (400 ft) include the Lynn Valley Tree and the Nooksack Giant.

The leaves are flat, soft, linear needles 1.5–4 cm (1⁄2–1+1⁄2 in) long,[19] generally resembling those of the firs, occurring singly rather than in fascicles; they completely encircle the branches, which can be useful in recognizing the species. As the trees grow taller in denser forest, they lose their lower branches, such that the foliage may start as high as 34 m (110 ft) off the ground.[20] Douglas-firs in environments with more light may have branches much closer to the ground.

The bark on young trees is thin, smooth, gray, and contains numerous resin blisters. On mature trees, usually exceeding 80 years,[citation needed] it is very thick and corky, growing up to 36 cm (14 in) thick with distinctive, deep vertical fissures caused by the gradual expansion of the growing tree. Some of the mature bark is brown, while other parts are lighter colored with a cork-like texture; these develop in multiple layers.[21] This thick bark makes the Douglas-fir one of the most fire-resistant tree native to the Pacific Northwest.[22]

The male cones are yellowish red, 5–12 mm (1⁄4–1⁄2 in) long. The female cones are green when young, maturing to reddish-brown or gray, 6–10 cm (2+1⁄4–4 in) long;[19] they are pendulous, with persistent scales, unlike those of true firs. They have distinctive long, trifid (three-pointed) bracts which protrude prominently above each scale and are said to resemble the back half of a mouse, with two feet and a tail.[23] The seeds are 5 mm (1⁄4 in) long, with a longer wing.[19]

The massive genome of Douglas-fir was sequenced in 2017 by the large PineRefSeq consortium, revealing a specialized photosynthetic apparatus in the light-harvesting complex of genes.[24]

Mature individual in the Wenatchee Mountains
Mature individual in the Wenatchee Mountains
Young female cone
Young female cone
Mature female cone
Mature female cone
TAXONOMY
The common name honors David Douglas, a Scottish botanist and collector who first reported the extraordinary nature and potential of the species. The common name is misleading since it is not a true fir, i.e., not a member of the genus Abies. For this reason, the name is often written as Douglas-fir (a name also used for the genus Pseudotsuga as a whole). Douglas' connection to the Douglas fir is told in the 1962 Death Valley Days episode 'Grass Man'.[15][25]

The specific epithet menziesii is after Archibald Menzies, a Scottish physician and rival naturalist to David Douglas. Menzies first documented the tree on Vancouver Island in 1791. Colloquially, the species is also known simply as Doug fir[9] or Douglas pine[9] (although the latter common name may also refer to Pinus douglasiana).[26] Other names for this tree have included Oregon pine,[8] British Columbian pine,[9] Puget Sound pine,[9] Douglas spruce,[9] false hemlock,[8] red fir,[8] or red pine[8] (although again red pine may refer to a different tree species, Pinus resinosa, and red fir may refer to Abies magnifica).[27]

One Coast Salish name for the tree, used in the Halkomelem language, is lá:yelhp.[28] In the Lushootseed language, the tree is called čəbidac.[29]

DISTRIBUTION
Pseudotsuga menziesii var. menziesii, the coast Douglas-fir, grows in the coastal regions from west-central British Columbia southward to Central California. In Oregon and Washington, its range is continuous from the eastern edge of the Cascades west to the Pacific Coast Ranges and Pacific Ocean. In California, it is found in the Klamath and California Coast Ranges as far south as the Santa Lucia Range, with a small stand as far south as the Purisima Hills in Santa Barbara County.[30][31] One of the last remaining old growth stands of conifers is in the Mattole Watershed, and is under threat of logging.[32][33] In the Sierra Nevada, it ranges as far south as the Yosemite region. It occurs from sea level along the coast to elevations of 1,500 m (4,900 ft) or higher, and inland in some cases up to 2,100 m (6,900 ft).[15]

Another variety exists further inland, Pseudotsuga menziesii var. glauca, the Rocky Mountain Douglas-fir or interior Douglas-fir. Interior Douglas-fir intergrades with coast Douglas-fir in the Cascades of northern Washington and southern British Columbia, and from there ranges northward to central British Columbia and southeastward to the Mexican border, becoming increasingly disjunct as latitude decreases and altitude increases. Mexican Douglas-fir (P. lindleyana), which ranges as far south as Oaxaca, is often considered a variety of P. menziesii.

Fossils (wood, pollen) of Pseudotsuga are recorded from the Miocene and Pliocene of Europe (Siebengebirge, Gleiwitz, Austria).[34]

It is also naturalised throughout Europe,[35] Argentina and Chile (called Pino Oregón). In New Zealand it is considered to be an invasive species, called a wilding conifer, and is subject to control measures. But is also one of the most common lumber trees used in forestry alongside Radiata pine with large plantations throughout the country. The species was introduced in the 20th century for its wood.[36][37]

ECOLOGY
Preferred sites
Douglas-fir prefers acidic or neutral soils, such as Olympic soil.[38] However, it exhibits considerable morphological plasticity, and on drier sites P. menziesii var. menziesii will generate deeper taproots. Pseudotsuga menziesii var. glauca exhibits even greater plasticity, occurring in stands of interior temperate rainforest in British Columbia, as well as at the edge of semi-arid sagebrush steppe throughout much of its range, where it generates even deeper taproots still.

The coast Douglas-fir variety is the dominant tree west of the Cascade Mountains in the Pacific Northwest. It occurs in nearly all forest types and competes well on most parent materials, aspects, and slopes. Adapted to a more moist, mild climate than the interior subspecies, it grows larger and faster than Rocky Mountain Douglas-fir. Associated trees include western hemlock, Sitka spruce, sugar pine, western white pine, ponderosa pine, grand fir, coast redwood, western redcedar, California incense-cedar, Lawson's cypress, tanoak, bigleaf maple and several others. Pure stands are also common, particularly north of the Umpqua River in Oregon. It is most dominant in areas with a more frequent fire regime that suppresses less fire-resistant conifers.[21]

Use by animals

A snag provides nest cavities for birds.
Douglas-fir seeds are an extremely important food source for small mammals such as moles, shrews, and chipmunks, which consume an estimated 65% of each annual seed crop. The Douglas squirrel harvests and hoards great quantities of Douglas-fir cones, and also consumes mature pollen cones, the inner bark, terminal shoots, and developing young needles.[14]

Mature or "old-growth" Douglas-fir forest is the primary habitat of the red tree vole (Arborimus longicaudus) and the spotted owl (Strix occidentalis). Home range requirements for breeding pairs of spotted owls are at least 400 hectares (4.0 km2; 990 acres) of old growth. Red tree voles may also be found in immature forests if Douglas-fir is a significant component. The red vole nests almost exclusively in the foliage of the trees, typically 2–50 metres (5–165 ft) above the ground, and its diet consists chiefly of Douglas-fir needles.[14]

Douglas-fir needles are generally poor browse for ungulates, although in the winter when other food sources are lacking it can become important, and black-tailed deer browse new seedlings and saplings in spring and summer. The spring diet of the blue grouse features Douglas-fir needles prominently.[14]

The leaves are also used by the woolly conifer aphid Adelges cooleyi; this 0.5 mm-long sap-sucking insect is conspicuous on the undersides of the leaves by the small white "fluff spots" of protective wax that it produces. It is often present in large numbers, and can cause the foliage to turn yellowish from the damage it causes. Exceptionally, trees may be partially defoliated by it, but the damage is rarely this severe. Among Lepidoptera, apart from some that feed on Pseudotsuga in general, the gelechiid moths Chionodes abella and C. periculella as well as the cone scale-eating tortrix moth Cydia illutana have been recorded specifically on P. menziesii.

The inner bark is the primary winter food for the North American porcupine.[14]

Poriol is a flavanone, a type of flavonoid, produced by P. menziesii in reaction to infection by Poria weirii.[39]

Value to other plants
A parasitic plant which uses P. menziesii is the Douglas-fir dwarf mistletoe (Arceuthobium douglasii). Epiphytes such as crustose lichens and mosses are common sights on Douglas-firs.[21] As it is only moderately shade tolerant,[15] undisturbed Douglas-fir stands in humid areas will eventually give way to later successional, more shade-tolerant associates such as the western redcedar and western hemlock—though this process may take a thousand years or more.[14] It is more shade tolerant than some associated fire-dependent species, such as western larch and ponderosa pine, and often replaces these species further inland.[15]

Diseases and insects
Fungal diseases such as laminated root rot and shoestring root-rot can cause significant damage, and in plantation settings dominated by Douglas-fir monocultures may cause extreme damage to vast swathes of trees.[14] Interplanting with resistant or nonhost species such as western redcedar and beaked hazelnut[40] can reduce this risk. Other threats to Douglas-fir include red ring rot and the Douglas-fir beetle.[14]

Uses

A 2.7 m (9 ft) log, scaling over 7,000 board feet (16,5 cubic meters) of timber, c. 1937
Many different Native American groups used the bark, resin, and needles to make herbal treatments for various diseases.[41] Native Hawaiians built waʻa kaulua (double-hulled canoes) from coast Douglas-fir logs that had drifted ashore.[42] The wood has historically been favored as firewood, especially from the coastal variety.[15] In addition early settlers used Douglas-fir for all forms of building construction, including floors, beams, and fine carving.

The species is extensively used in forestry management as a plantation tree for softwood timber. Douglas-fir is one of the world's best timber-producing species and yields more timber than any other species in North America, making the forestlands of western Oregon, Washington, and British Columbia the most productive on the continent. In 2011, Douglas-fir represented 34.2% of US lumber exports, to a total of 1.053 billion board feet (2,484,803,3 cubic meters).[43][14] Douglas-fir timber is used for timber frame construction and timber trusses using traditional joinery, veneer, and flooring due to its strength, hardness and durability.[44] As of 2024, the only wooden ships still currently in use by the U.S. Navy in conventional naval operations are Avenger-class minesweepers, made of Douglas-fir.[45]

Douglas-fir sees wide use in heavy timber structures, as its wood is strong, available in a number of specifications including kiln dried and grade stamped, and can be supplied in very long lengths to 18 m (60 ft). West coast mills are sophisticated in their processing of timbers, making lead times predictable and availability reliable. Paints adhere well to Douglas-fir. Stains perform well on Douglas-fir timbers with the mild caution that the natural color of this species varies and care must be taken to ensure uniformity of color. Pitch pockets that may ooze resin can be present in timbers that have not been kiln dried. Because of the timber sizes available, stamped timber grading, and relatively short lead times, Douglas-fir sees wide use in both public and residential projects.[citation needed]

The species has ornamental value in large parks and gardens.[46] It has been commonly used as a Christmas tree since the 1920s, and the trees are typically grown on plantations.[47]

The buds have been used to flavor eau de vie, a clear, colorless fruit brandy.[48] Douglas-fir pine leaves can be used to make pine needle tea.[49] They possess a tangy citrus flavor and may serve in some recipes as a wild substitute for rosemary.[50]

prompt:
My financials are in a bit of shambles at the moment, so I want to create a new budget in Microsoft Excel from scratch. I've got this book I can't seem to remember to use, but it has sections for monthly goals, a calendar to track bills and whatnot, some sort of checklist I'm not sure what I'm supposed to do with, and a few pages to track expenses. This is a part I struggle with. I don't keep a daily track of my expenses, but I do have credit card statements I could pull and upload if there's an easy way to connect them to the system. Also, I don't want to have to repopulate all this information for each month, so everything needs to be dynamic, with all the data connecting in the most efficient way. 

With all that said, first, can you give me a couple of layout ideas and the important categories to include, such as, but not limited to: Financial Goals, Monthly Objectives, Long-Term Plan, Debt Repayment Schedule, fixed and variable expenses tables with areas for like, subscriptions or projected groceries, a dynamic calendar that updates each month, and somewhere to track daily/weekly income and expenses. I'm looking for what should be on the screen first, ya know, like I should remind myself of what goal I'm aiming towards, or what reward is linked to this financial goal, because I don't want to pull up the document and immediately see the "total debt" in big red letters staring me in the face. And since this is in Excel, the goals can be in the top left, with the calendar to the right or underneath, or an expense tracker on the far right of the same sheet for simple formulas, or in a new sheet for better aesthetic formatting. Layout suggestions like that, because I can scroll around the sheet, and I think this will be a pretty big running document.

After a couple of layout suggestions, the real fun begins. I need a step-by-step method of how to create a dynamic calendar table. I believe I can set up formulas to populate a basic table with the correct date for each day of the week, so it matches the current year and weekly schedule, and I can just copy and paste for each new month. I also want to be able to take notes here, so would it be cool to have a dropdown menu to change the day's color, or some sort of conditional formatting that shows if a bill is due on that day, or like green for when I'm supposed to track my income each week? Don't worry about any formulas for this section aside from creating the basic dynamic calendar, but with the idea of dropdown menus, include a few suggestions for other enhancements for this calendar that would be helpful to include as part of a dynamic budget, such as having a cell at the end of the week that calculates total income-expenses or something.

Also, how do I simply upload an exported credit card statement, and connect whatever charges show up to a more organized expense report from multiple statements into a long list of each charge, but that also condenses this information in another, more compact table that pulls the monthly charges or potentially even separates the numbers by which report they came from? I don't know, this area I need suggestions with, because what are my options to simplify these expense reports in a way that I don't have to manually transfer all of this information, and can offload the stress of tracking my expenses on a weekly basis, that also adheres to the logic of Excel. Include whatever pertinent options Excel offers for this, but provide only a brief elaboration on the formula and how difficult the process would be, without going into a step-by-step explanation just yet.

Finally, are there any areas of a personal budget that I should include? Any specific graphs, pivot tables, or other methods of formatting, whether useful or aesthetic, that I should consider including in this budget to make my life easier?
rubrics: The response should provide at least two suggestions for a financial budget layout within Microsoft Excel.

The response should include suggestions for categories to include within a personal financial budget. For example, it could include goals, projected income, planned expenses, a debt-repayment plan, and/or a savings fund.
The response should include layout suggestions that showcase the user's financial goals or a similar positive "attention-grabbing" category as the primary information shown when opening the document.
The response should include a step-by-step explanation on how to create a dynamic calendar in Microsoft Excel.

The instructions for the dynamic calendar should include accurate formulas, functional in Microsoft Excel, that populate the correct date correlated to a Sunday through Saturday weekly schedule. For example, it could use the formula "=DATE(YEAR, MONTH,1)-WEEKDAY(DATE(YEAR, MONTH,1),1)+1" which correctly identifies the first Sunday in this calendar format.
The dynamic calendar should include an area for "Notes."
The response should include at least one suggestion for using Conditional Formatting in Microsoft Excel for a dynamic calendar.
The response should not include specific formulas when suggesting additional calendar enhancements aside from populating the current dates.

The response should include an explanation on how to export financial statements and upload them for use inside the Microsoft Excel document. For example, it could suggest using the Excel function, "Power Query."
The response should not include a step-by-step process for importing financial documents. For example, it should not include specific formulas for expense reporting or data extraction.

The response should include additional suggestions that could improve the financial budget being created in Microsoft Excel. For example, it could include suggestions to create pivot tables, aesthetic upgrades, or specific formulas to look out for to condense unwanted information.
The response should provide a brief elaboration on the difficulty of the suggested options for importing credit card statements.
The response should suggest methods for summarizing imported credit card data into a compact table. For example, it could suggest using Pivot Tables to group expenses by category.

prompt:
I'm a songwriter and I'm looking for inspiration for my next EP. I want you to help me create a track sequence, and I'm trying to tell a story. I've got a few rules:

List my tracks in a table chart format, and I'd like the columns to be labeled, "Song Length- Song Name- Main Instruments- Genre/Vibe", so it's easy to read and understand.
For the "Main instruments" tab, I want the three most prominent instruments listed for the track (Piano, synth, violin, exc.), with the main instrument in bold. If vocals should be used, list them as an extra fourth instrument.
For the "Genre/Vibe" tab, I want the genre listed (Rap, rock, RnB) as well as the vibe of the song (Sad, happy, confused). I want the song title to reflect the vibe.
I would like 9-11 tracks, however I only have the studio time to make a 35 minute EP. I don't want a song shorter than 2:50 minutes, but I also don't want a song longer than 5:30 minutes.
I really am familiar with Piano, Violin, and Electric Guitar, so make sure they all get three songs each where they are the main instruments each. Piano and violin should never be back to back, though, their vibe is too similar... and no instrument should be the main instrument twice in a row, to keep things from being repetitive.
Give the acoustic guitar one song that is five minutes or more as well. I'm learning it right now, so I want to test myself.
I also want my EP to have a triumphant feel, start it off low and go through a sad point, but end it happy and hopeful. Have the song names reflect it.

Can you draft a track order that satisfies all of these requirements?
rubrics: The response should present the tracklist in a table or chart format.
The response should label the columns of the table, in order, as: "Song Length", "Song Name", "Main Instruments", "Genre/Vibe".
The response should list a total of 9, 10, or 11 tracks.
The total running time of all listed tracks, when summed, should be no longer than 35 minutes.
The response should not list any song with a "Song Length" shorter than 2 minutes and 50 seconds (2:50).
The response should not list any song with a "Song Length" longer than 5 minutes and 30 seconds (5:30).
The 'Main Instruments' column for each track should contain exactly three instruments, or exactly four items if the fourth is 'Vocals'
For each track, exactly one instrument in the "Main Instruments" column should be formatted in bold.
If "vocals" are listed for a track in the "Main Instruments" column, they should be listed as a fourth instrument in addition to the three other instruments.
For each track, the "Genre/Vibe" column should contain both a musical genre (e.g., Rock, RnB, Indie) and an emotional vibe (e.g., Sad, Hopeful, Confused).
The response should list three tracks where the Piano is the main (bolded) instrument.
The response should list three tracks where the Violin is the main (bolded) instrument.
The response should list three tracks where the Electric Guitar is the main (bolded) instrument.
Neither the prompt or the criterion suggest there needs to be exactly three tracks with one of those instruments, only that there needs to be at least three.
The response should not list a track with Piano as the main (bolded) instrument immediately before or after a track with Violin as the main (bolded) instrument.
The response should not list two consecutive tracks that have the same main (bolded) instrument.

The "Song Name" for each track should correspond to the "Vibe" listed in the "Genre/Vibe" column. For example, a song with a "Sad" vibe could be titled "Fading Light," while a "Hopeful" song could be titled "New Dawn."

The sequence of "Vibes" listed in the "Genre/Vibe" column should follow a triumphant arc. For example, the tracklist should start with low or somber vibes, transition to sad or despairing vibes, and conclude with happy or hopeful vibes.

The sequence of "Song Names" should reflect a triumphant story arc. For example, early track names could suggest struggle like "Empty Room" or "Fading Echoes," while later tracks could suggest resolution like "First Light" or "The Summit."
The response should list exactly one track where the Acoustic Guitar is the main (bolded) instrument.
The track where the Acoustic Guitar is the main (bolded) instrument should have a "Song Length" of 5 minutes (5:00) or more.

Megan, Kaitlin, Aspen, Greg, Michael, Steven, Brooke, Perry, Felicia, Bob

Forgot to mention, Michael and Megan do not drink so please don't assign them to bring alcohol. I'm Bob, and please assign me to bring the pizzas and an alcoholic drink. Actually list the specific drink or dish people should bring so we make sure to get variety but don't include anything with peanuts or dairy (besides the pizza as I will be bring 1 dairy-free option) as we have some people with allergies/intolerances.

The response should be a memo about an office party on Friday, Nov. 21st at 6pm in the break room.

The memo should include that attendance at the office party is not mandatory, but strongly encouraged. For example, the memo could explain that the office party will be a great chance to hang out, but employees are not required to be there.
The memo should not assign alcoholic drinks to Michael  or Megan.
The memo should assign the 3 pizzas and an alcoholic drink to Bob.
The memo should include that one of the pizzas Bob is bringing will be dairy-free.

The memo should assign specific food and drink items to each office worker rather than simply assigning food and drink categories. For example, the memo could assign "corn chips and guacamole" instead of "chip/dip combo."

prompt:
LESSON MAKER PRO:

Sometimes I don’t have enough time to create new lesson plans and quizzes for my weekly online English class, so if you could help me, that would be great! I’ll tell you what I typically want, enter that week's data, and you’ll be able to spit something out for me and save me a bunch of time. By the way, my students are around 12 or 13 years old, and English is their second language (after Mandarin), so please keep all explanations and instructions simple so they can understand.  

Each of my lessons usually consists of four components:

INTRODUCTION: 

First, I introduce a new topic to my students, often a new grammar rule or vocabulary exercise. This section will also have the title of the day’s learning goals, so make sure to include that. 

If it’s a grammar day - I like to start simple by breaking down the grammar rule into its simplest form, with a few (2 or 3) concrete examples that my students can relate to or understand. If a few of my examples are about Taiwan, my students seem to pay more attention, so please strive for this in about 20% of your examples throughout. The most important thing here is teaching the students WHY, WHEN, and HOW to use this particular grammar rule, so please break this down clearly, with each of those question words as a mini-section with a short but meaningful explanation for each. 

If it’s a vocabulary day, I always stick to a theme for the lesson, whether that’s a real-world theme (like the ocean, for example) or a phonetic theme (like words that use “gh” together). Since these kids are relatively new learners of English, let’s keep the words fun and non-scientific (think sharks and seaweed instead of salinity or acidification). Our vocabulary list will be ten words long, and each word should include a simple sentence using the word correctly. If a word is a plural form, or a verb conjugation, there should be a note about that as well so the students understand that this is not the base form of the word. But these instances shouldn’t account for more than 10% of total words (1 out of 10). 

 EXAMPLES: 

This section is about real-world applications of either the new grammar rule or the new vocabulary words. Essentially, this section will be a sample paragraph that either utilizes the new grammar rule 3 or 4 times or, if we’re doing vocabulary, the paragraph will include all 10 words naturally. These paragraphs should include at least one reference to Taiwan or Taiwanese culture. I will break down this paragraph to show students the new rules or words being utilized, and have them read it aloud as well. 

QUIZ: 

Lastly, once we have become familiar with the new concepts, I will quiz the students on what they have learned (always ten questions in a numbered list). My quizzes are either multiple-choice for grammar rules, with a clear indication of the words/phrases they can use for their answers (A, B, C, or D), or fill-in-the-blank for vocabulary (with a corresponding list of words they can choose from).  

For grammar, the quiz must test the students' understanding of the new concept. If they’re learning verb conjugation, there must be multiple forms of the verb being tested in the possible answer section (walk or walks vs walked, for example). 

For vocabulary, each question would correspond to one of the new words we learned, testing their ability to understand the sentence and enter the correct word. The answer key list will show all ten words. 

The quiz should include rules at the top explaining what students are supposed to do. Please leave a blank space or underline where the answer will go in the question. The vocabulary list should be scrambled, so that the answer for question one would not necessarily be the first word on the answer key list. For grammar, please randomize the correct answer (so that not every answer is A, for example). 

FOR TEACHER (on a separate page):

The last section will be an answer key for the quiz that I can print out to help me with grading. I need you to bold the correct multiple choice answer for easy reading, and input the correct answer in bold in the question, and the vocabulary questions should have the correct word inputted in bold in the blank space. 

That’s it, so every time I need a new lesson I can input it below here:

Lesson 2: In the garden!

Goal: Help students learn new garden-themed vocabulary words! This can include plants, animals, tools, etc., that one would see or use in the garden.
rubrics: The response should be structured into four main sections, in the following order: INTRODUCTION, EXAMPLES, QUIZ, and FOR TEACHER.

The response should use simple language, explanations, and instructions suitable for 12-13 year old English second language learners. For example, sentences should be short, and vocabulary should avoid complex or overly technical terms.
The INTRODUCTION section should contain a title that states the lesson's learning goals, such as "Learning Goals: Garden-themed Vocabulary Words!".
The lesson's content should be based on the theme "In the garden!", using vocabulary related to plants, animals, tools, or other items one might find in a garden.
The chosen vocabulary words should be fun and non-scientific. For example, words like "shovel" or "butterfly" are appropriate, while words like "photosynthesis" or "pollination" are not.
The INTRODUCTION section should provide a list of exactly 10 vocabulary words.
Each of the 10 vocabulary words in the list should be accompanied by a simple sentence demonstrating its correct usage.
The response should include a note explaining that a word is not in its base form if any of the 10 vocabulary words is a plural or a verb conjugation.
Model A made a note that "Weeds" is the plural form of the word, but failed to make a note that "Seeds" is the plural form of the word.
The response should not include more than one vocabulary word (out of 10) that is a plural form or a verb conjugation.
The EXAMPLES section should contain a single sample paragraph.

I understand that both models "failed" this criteria test when run through the AI checker, but for the purposes of this exercise, I do not believe that including a short introduction sentence before the paragraph would represent major instruction following failure. This  "failure" isn't really in the spirit of the exercise, and neither did the prompt explicitly say that a short introduction to the paragraph was prohibited.
The paragraph in the EXAMPLES section should use all 10 vocabulary words from the INTRODUCTION section.
The paragraph in the EXAMPLES section should contain at least one reference to Taiwan or Taiwanese culture.
The QUIZ section should contain a numbered list of exactly 10 questions.
The QUIZ section should start with a set of rules that explain to the students what they are supposed to do.
The quiz questions should be in a fill-in-the-blank format.
Each quiz question should have a visible blank space or an underline where the student should write their answer.
The quiz should provide a list of all 10 vocabulary words from the lesson for students to use as a word bank.
The word bank for the quiz should be in a scrambled order, where the order of words does not match the order of the questions.
The "FOR TEACHER" section should be clearly separated from the student-facing sections using a page break or a note indicating a page break.
The "FOR TEACHER" section should contain a complete answer key for the 10-question quiz.
The answer key should show the quiz questions with the correct vocabulary word filled into the blank space for each question.
In the answer key, the correct word that is filled into the blank space for each question should be formatted in **bold**.

The vocabulary words should be integrated naturally into the EXAMPLES paragraph. For example, the paragraph should read like a coherent story and not just a list of sentences that happen to contain the vocabulary words.

prompt:
We have had a lot of turnover in my department because new hires say they just don't understand what we do and why, which makes them not feel a part of...I really need you to create a document I can give to new hires that will explain all these aspects

The Department is - Supply Planning and Logistics. The job title is - Logistics Coordinator.
Before this job even comes into play: Our Customers order online or call in. Customer Service Reps (CSRs) process orders in customer portal, then submits sales order. Buyer (interchangeably called Supply Planners at our company) submit the Purchase Order (PO) to our vendors. Once the planner receives the order confirmation, We then get referred the purchase order.

Main things we review on purchase orders:
* Quantity: Our company only orders in Truckloads which are roughly ~38 to 45,000 lbs, or Railcars which are 60,000+ lbs
* Ship Types: Bulk, or pre-packaged: bags or drums
* Incoterms. What we use - DDP, FCA, EXW, DAP, and CPT. We also use PPA (prepay add), just less frequently
What the employee does
- determine ftl or rc
- determine bulk or packaged
- determine inco term
* Based on the incoterm - if OUR company arranges freight FROM THE START, PO gets referred to the freight coordinators. Why? - they will arrange freight. If OUR company DOES NOT arrange freight from the start, it gets sent to procurement coordinators. Why? - they will coordinate with our warehouses so they can prepare for product delivery.
- Once the product arrives at our warehouses (however it does) our personal fleet then distributes it to the end customers. 

The POs will explicitly say applicable things "Truck" "Drums" "EXW" etc, but the worker will start to know shorthand codes which are

any incoterms We arrange freight - ZX1
any incoterms Seller arrange freight - ZX5
Bulk - ISO
PrePackaged - PKG-and then either BAG or DR (so it will either be PKG-BAG or PKG-DR)
Truck - FTL
Rail - RC

Examples: 
1. We receive a PO at 43,643 lbs. FCA bags

----

Please set up a document using the above information and these format instructions in this order:

Department Title
Job Title
Bullet list of the PRIMARY departments we work with (the stated steps before us and the referrals immediately after us) - just department names
- numbered list with work flow of before PO referred to us.
2-3 sentence Description of what we then do (reviewing POs, tracking logistic type for referall to necessary next step in the chain, etc. 

Transport type  (no acronyms/codes) with breakdown of weights
bulk/package (no acronyms/codes) types 
Then brief description of wht an incoterm is (1 sentence). THEN create 2 groups with titles indicating the incoterms we arrange and the ones the seller arrange - (No PO codes in these titles) - then  acronyms and full names as internationally known in each. within each section, after the applicable incoterms, say which depts get referral. 

Then, from previously stated, do a full list of PO codes (acronyms and full terms)  the employee  can look for on the POs

Lastly, write out the example I gave and create 4 more varied examples. Keep those in the brief format similar to mine. 

(in a separate section after the main document, restate the examples and give me the answers in our tracking form, which is: [incoterm type either ZX1 or ZX5],[transport method],[package method]. No explanation of answers necessary i will say that myself when training the employee)

Just create the requests above, no preamble or added conclusions in ur response.
rubrics: The response should begin the document with the department title, "Supply Planning and Logistics".
The response should state the job title, "Logistics Coordinator".

The response should have a bullet list of the primary departments the logistics coordinator works with: Customer Service (CSRs), Supply Planning (also known as Buyers), Freight Coordinators, Procurement Coordinators.

The response should have a numbered list with a workflow of what happens before the PO reaches the Logistics Coordinator. For example, it can say 1. Customer places an order, 2. CSR submits a sales order, 3. Buyer submits a PO, 4. Vendor confirms PO, 5. PO referred to the Logistics Coordinator.

The response should have a section that provides a 2-3 sentence description of what the Logistics Coordinator does. For example, it can say, "Job Description:" and then have 2-3 sentences about how the logistics coordinator reviews/analyzes POs, tracks logistics like shipping types/amounts/incoterms, and then refers the PO to the next departmental role in the supply chain.

The job description section should describe the position as the user has described it in the prompt. For example, the user has clearly described the position as one that follows an objective workflow process, so the response ought to describe the position as a "Purchase order reviewer" or "Key analyzer" position, not a "key decision maker" position, since no subjective decisions are made in this role.
The response should have a section for transport types and weights, with truckloads (about 38-45,000 lbs) and railcars (60,000+ lbs).

The response should have a section that list bulk and pre-packaged as container types. For example, it could say "Shipment Type: Bulk and Prepackaged" or "Containers: Bulk - tanker or railcar, Pre-packaged - bags and drums."
The response should not use acronyms/codes in the transport type and container type sections.
The response should have a 1 sentence description of what an incoterm is. For example, it can say it is a term that designates the responsibilities of a buyer and seller in shipment delivery.

The response should have 2 groups with titles indicating if the user's company ("we") arrange freight, or if the seller arranges freight without any PO-code acronyms. For example, the titles could be "We Arrange" and "Seller Arranges"
The response should say that Freight Coordinators get "We Arrange" incoterm-types and that Procurement Coordinators get "Seller Arrange" incoterm types.

The response should not add any extra parts to the incoterm classification section besides what the instructions explicitly say to have there, which are the category titles ("We arrange" and "seller arrange"), list of incoterms in each, and info about department referral info. For example, the response should not put extra information about who is in charge of arranging freight since the titles already say that.
The response should include a complete list of PO codes, showing each acronym (e.g., ZX1, ZX5, ISO, PKG‑BAG, PKG‑DR, FTL, RC) together with its full meaning, in a separate “PO Codes” section.

Biologically, it presented a fasting plasma glucose of 115 and HbA1C of 6.7%. Associated, the patient has chronic kidney disease G4A3 KDIGO, severe proliferative diabetic retinopathy, a history of chronic alcohol consumption with hepatic cirrhosis Child Pugh class B, moderate anemia with a count of 25.000 leucocites and 22.000 neutrophils.
I want you to write a case presentation medical essay based on the strict instructions provided by me. You have to be neutral, concise and talk strictly about the subject. Do not use interjections or adjectives; respect a medical professional language. For each diabetes information, provide the reference from the latest ADA guidelines available online and include it in brackets after the information. All information should be from the latest guidelines, but not all must be referenced in the essay, just the diabetes one.
1.	Rewrite the patient description in a natural and fluent language, with logically sorted symptoms, findings and associated pathology. List them systematically with 3 bullet points. Each point must represent a category, not a singular finding. Bold the category word.
2.	Write 2 paragraphs about the general definition of each disease presented, with diagnostic criteria from the latest international guidelines available on the internet.
3.	In another paragraph, define if the patient fulfills diabetes diagnostic criteria and if the diabetes can be confirmed or not. If not, present which are the 3 next steps that must be followed.
4.	From now on, each instruction must be written in a three-sentence paragraph, adapting it specifically if the point mentions so.
5.	Present the interpretation of anemia and neoplasm-suggesting symptoms, and integrate the information into a conclusion.

7.	Describe the metformin initiation treatment pro and cons arguments. In this case, the paragraph must contain two sentences, one with pro and one with con arguments. Instead of the last sentence, create a list with pro and con arguments. Draw a conclusion at the end of the paragraph
9.	List the next 2 steps for evaluating the hepatic function and structure.
10.	Describe the hepatic cancer risk implied by hepatic cirrhosis and how why it would be relevant in this use case.
11.	Define the next steps that should be taken into account regarding the chronic kidney disease future management in this case. Here I need you to write a single sentence and a list with 3 steps needed.
12.	 Write 5 questions for using them in anamnesis to find the most probable cause of elevated white blood cells count. Define what elevated neutrophils indicate.

You must not:

The words bolded must be carefully chosen to be useful in generating a title just by adding two or three words in addition to them. prompt:
Help me craft a multiplication test for my 3rd-grade class. They've learned the multiplication chart from the 0s to the 12s, so they should be able to multiply any number 0-12 by another number 0-12.

I'd like the test to be made up of a table with 5 columns and 12 rows. Each cell in the table will contain one multiplication question that fits the class' level. First, each cell should be numbered going across horizontally first, and then continued on the next row. Then I need each cell to have the multiplication question, but I want the numbers in each question not to be a repeat of the question that comes before or after. For example, if question 2 is 7×3=, then questions 1 and 3 should not have 7 or 3 in the question. This way, the numbers are mixed up, and the students will operate more from memory, instead of using addition in their heads or anything like that. It's supposed to be memorized.

Above that, I would like a large-text title, followed by instructions. The instructions should be 1-3 sentences that explain to my students how to set up their page. I want them to fold their paper in half to create a crease down the middle of the page. Open it back up and number each line vertically, then continue next to the crease, then on the back. They should put the question number, followed by the equation, then the answer on their page. Their name the the math test title should go at the top. Explain this in a way that the class can understand and follow the instructions. They will have 10 minutes; make sure that's in the instructions too. Make sure the instructions, question numbers, and questions are in plain text.

Underneath the table with the questions, I needed the table repeated, but I need the answers included. It should match the first table exactly, but it should include the answers bolded.

The idea is that I will show the questions on the projection screen, and they will take their test on a separate sheet of paper. When they are done, they will pass their papers to their neighbor. I will scroll down the test so that the answers are shown, and the students will grade the papers by making sure the answers are correct.
rubrics: The response should provide a title for the multiplication test using a larger font size than the rest of the response.
The response should provide student instructions after the title and before the first table.
The response should provide student instructions that are between 1 and 3 sentences in length.

The response should give instructions that are written in a way that is easy for 3rd-grade students to understand. For example, it should use direct commands and simple vocabulary, like "up and down" instead of "vertically."
The response should give instructions that state that the students have 10 minutes to complete the test.
The response should give instructions that tell students to write their name and the test title at the top of their paper.

The response should give instructions that state how to prepare the answer sheet, including folding the paper in half to create a crease, opening it back up, and numbering the lines down the page on both sides of the crease, and continuing on the back.

Both responses contain most of the instructions, but neither response includes the step to continue the numbering on the back. Model A also failed to include that the numbering should happen on both sides of the crease. Since the responses got most of the instructions, I marked these are minor issues.
The response should give instructions that say that the answers should be formatted with the question number, followed by the full question, and then the answer.
The response should generate a multiplication test in the form of a table with a multiplication question in each cell.
The response should generate a multiplication test in the form of a table with 5 columns and 12 rows.
The response should generate a multiplication test where each question contains only factors between 0 and 12.
The response should number each question in the multiplication test in order, going across horizontally and continuing on the next row.

The response should avoid repeating factors in a question if they were used in the immediately preceding or succeeding question. For example, if question 2 is 7×3=, then question 1 and question 3 cannot contain the numbers 7 or 3.

The response should make sure the instructions, question numbers, and questions are in plain text. For example, the instructions, question numbers, and questions should not be bolded or italicized, excluding the title and answers.
The response should include a second table, located underneath the first table.

The response should duplicate the first table in the second table in terms of its dimensions (5 columns, 12 rows) and the multiplication questions in each cell, with only the addition of the answers to each equation.
The response should bold the answers to the questions in the second table.

prompt:
I’m running a homeschooling/unschooling group over the summer next summer for families who are interested in trying out homeschooling first without committing to it during a school year. I want to arrange a weekly schedule.
We will run every day except Saturdays, and Sundays will be family day, so that the parents can come and be part of the learning. We will run Mondays - Fridays 9am - 3pm, and Sundays 12 - 6pm. Make sure to schedule lunch every school day at 12, except for Sunday, which should have lunch scheduled for 1pm. Make sure to always schedule a physical activity for the hour slot before lunch. Schedule all classes or activities in one hour blocks. Make sure to schedule 3 gardening/nature classes a week. Schedule exactly one physical activity activity per school day. The physical activities you can choose from are: dance, hiking, maypole, and pool time. Please schedule pool time and dance twice each per week, and the others once per week each. Do not schedule pool time on Sundays; schedule dance on Sundays, as it’s a nice activity to do with family and community. Every school day the kids should have 2 hour blocks of free play, but never back to back hours. Please schedule 3 farm animal slots per week, where we spend time with and learn about our property’s animals. Schedule 3 art slots per week (we don’t decide what art to do, they pick what they want to do that day based on what we have available).  Schedule 3 science activities per week. The specific projects will be chosen later. 
Please make sure not to schedule any of the same classes on back to back days, so the kids feel a nice variety throughout the week. Make sure the parents experience an art class and either nature class or science class. Never repeat the same daily class combination, meaning, if one days’ classes are 2 free play blocks, dance, science, and farm animals, no other day in the week should have that same combination of classes. We do this because some kids only come 2 days, 3 days, or 4 days a week, and we don’t want them to have repeated days as their only class days.
