prompt:
Please help me convert the following crochet pattern so that I can follow it more easily. The pattern in written using UK terms, but I prefer US terms. Below the pattern, I will paste a table explaining the difference between the UK and US terminology for you to use in your conversion. Replace the asterisks surrounding the repeated pattern parts (for example, the asterisks in "*Ch 3, Sk 5 Ch, V in next Ch* repeat 8 more times") with brackets, and replace any instances of the text "repeat # more times" with "x#". Replace the row summaries that follow each row in parentheses with a total stitch count for that row.  After each summary, indicate the total number of stitches in that row. For this count any decrease stitches as 1 stitch, increase stitches as 2 stitches, and V stitches as 3 stitches.  Rewrite any text that is not part of a stitch abbreviation (like the words 'in', 'from', and 'hook' in "in 4th ch from hook") in italics. 
---
Grattitude Wrap (Crochet): 

Stitch abbreviations:
 Ch - Chain
 Dc - Double crochet
 Tr - Treble
 V - V Stitch (Tr, Ch 1, Tr in the same space)
 St - Stitch
 Sk - Skip
 Sp - Space
 Sl St - Slip Stitch

Pattern: 
Ch 64

Row 1:
 Tr in 4th Ch from the hook, *Ch 3, Sk 5 Ch, V in next Ch* repeat 8 more times
 Ch 3, Sk 5 Ch, 2 Tr in last Ch, turn
(4 x Tr, 9 x V, 10 x Ch 3)

Row 2:
 Ch 3 (counts as a Tr here and throughout), Tr between 2 Tr of previous row,
 *Ch 2, Dc on Ch 3 Sp, Ch 2, V in V of previous row* repeat 8 more times
 Ch 2, Dc on Ch 3 Sp, Ch 2, 2 Tr between last 2 Tr of previous row, turn
(4 x Tr, 20 x Ch 2, 10 x Dc, 9 x V)

Row 3:
 Ch 3, Tr between 2 Tr of previous row, *Ch 3, Sk (Ch2, Dc, Ch 2), V in next V of previous row* repeat 8 more times
 Ch 3, 2 Tr between last 2 Tr of previous row, turn 
(4 x Tr, 9 x V, 10 x Ch 3)

Repeat rows 2 & 3 for a total of 50 rows, finish on a Row 2 repeat
---

UK vs US crochet terms: 

| UK Abbrev | UK Name               | US Abbrev | US Name                      |
|-----------|------------------------|-----------|-------------------------------|
| Sl st     | Slip stitch            | Sl st     | Slip stitch                   |
| ch        | Chain                  | ch        | Chain                         |
| dc        | Double crochet         | sc        | Single crochet                |
| htr       | Half treble crochet    | hdc       | Half double crochet           |
| tr        | Treble crochet         | dc        | Double crochet                |
| dtr       | Double treble          | tr        | Triple crochet                |
| RtrF      | Raised treble front    | FPdc      | Front Post double crochet     |
| RtrB      | Raised treble back     | BPdc      | Back Post double crochet      |
rubrics: The response should use brackets to enclose repeated sections of the crochet pattern.
The response should not use asterisks in the crochet pattern (aside from those used for markdown formatting).
The response should follow any bracketed portions of the crochet pattern with an “x#”, with the # indicating the total number of times that bracketed portion should be repeated.
The response should not use the phrase “repeat # more times”.
The response should follow all crochet pattern rows with a total stitch count.

The response should count all increase crochet stitches (multiple stitches worked into one previous stitch) as two stitches in each row’s total stitch count. For example, "2 dc in last Ch" is an increase stitch and would be counted as two stitches.
The response should count all V stitches as three stitches in each row’s total stitch count.
The response should count all chain stitches as one stitch in each row’s total stitch count.
The response should count all single crochet stitches as one stitch in each row’s total stitch count.
The response should count all double crochet stitches as one stitch in each row’s total stitch count.
The response should not count any skipped stitches in each row’s total stitch count.

The response should write all crochet pattern text that is not part of a stitch abbreviation in italics. For example, the words 'in', 'from', and 'hook' in the pattern portion "in 4th ch from hook" should be italicized.

The response should not include any treble crochet stitches in the crochet pattern (not including the abbreviations list), because no stitches in the original UK pattern convert to it based on the provided table. This
The response should indicate that the total stitch count for row 1 is 61.
The response should indicate that the total stitch count for row 2 is 81.
The response should indicate that the total stitch count for row 3 is 61.

The response should rewrite the V stitch formula using US crochet terms. For example, the V stitch formula should read "(dc, ch 1, dc in the same space)" instead of the UK version "(tr, ch 1, tr in the same space)".
The response should include the initial chain instruction, "Ch 64", at the beginning of the pattern.
The response should include the final instruction from the pattern: "Repeat rows 2 & 3 for a total of 50 rows, finish on a Row 2 repeat"

The response should not include the original row summaries in parentheses. For example, it should not include (4 x Tr, 9 x V, 10 x Ch 3) after the instructions for row 1, though it may include total stitch counts in parentheses.
The response should correctly interpret "repeat 8 more times" as a total of nine repetitions. For example, the original text "repeat 8 more times" should be replaced with "x9".
The response should maintain the original structure of the user-provided text. For example, it should present the stitch abbreviations first, followed by the main pattern instructions.
The response should maintain the original crochet pattern title “Grattitude Wrap (Crochet)”.
The response should not include the UK vs US crochet terms conversion table that was provided in the prompt for reference.

The response should provide the pattern instructions using the US abbreviation "sc" (single crochet) in place of the UK abbreviation "Dc" (double crochet). For example, "Dc on Ch 3 Sp" should become "sc on Ch 3 Sp"

prompt:
I need some help making our holiday donation campaign materials. Our company name is "The Puzzle People" and every holiday we run a campaign to raise money for the needy. This year we are fundraising for The Trevor Project. The campaign will be six word puzzles. One puzzle will be sent once a week to our subscribers. The puzzles should get harder each week and no answers can be reused in other weeks. Once someone has the answers to all 6 puzzles they will have one final puzzle to conclude the campaign. Putting the 6 previous answers in order will be an acrostic where the first letter of each answer should spell "DONATE". We are using four puzzle types for the campaign. You can reuse them but you must use every type at least once

PUZZLE TYPES

Scramble - Providing a word where the letters are scrambled up and the user must put them in the right order to reveal a hidden word

Fill-in-the-blank - A sentence missing some words

Interwoven Strings - a type of word puzzle in which two or more strings of text (often crossword-style clues) are interwoven in a way that each one can be read in the correct way by simply skipping over the letters from the other string. 

Double puzzle -  The first step is to unscramble the letters found within the puzzle. The second step is to take specific letters from the unscrambled words and use those letters to decrypt a phrase of some kind

PUZZLE DO
- Every puzzle should have a holiday theme.
- Puzzle should get harder each week. This can be both just the challenge of the puzzle but also the type. For example, once you use a double puzzle, subsequent weeks shouldn't use a regular scramble


PUZZLE DON'T
- None of them should be explicitly religious.
- No puzzle answer should be a repeat of a previous week


The other part of your task is to take each puzzle and put them in a template email to send out once per week. In each email put the solution to the previous weeks puzzle and then include the current week's puzzle. Include our name and who we are fundraising for in each email. The two special cases for emails is the first email and the last email. The first should announce our campaign and have the first weeks puzzle as well as a teaser that all the puzzles are connected. The last should thank everyone for donating, wish them a happy holidays, and include all the answers for all the puzzles including the acrostic.
rubrics: The response should contain 7 puzzles.
Neither response contains a final puzzle, they both present a solution only.
The response should contain 7 template emails that each contain a puzzle.

Response A does not have a puzzle in the final email, just a solution to one.
Response B does not have an email for it's 6th puzzle.
The response should include the company name "The Puzzle People" in every email.
The response should include the recipient of the fundraiser, "The Trevor Project", in every email.
The response should have all puzzles be holiday themed. For example, it could use winter imagery like snowflakes or reference holiday media like the Nutcracker.

Response A has minor issues as it is mostly related holiday themed. It does have some more generic concepts like "appreciation" which are vaguely holiday.
Response B has gibberish answers ("aightime") and unrelated answers ("digest") so it has major issues with this criterion.
The response should have unique answers for each puzzle.

Response A has no issues with this criterion.
Response B has a unique answer for each puzzle but since so many of them are gibberish the model cannot understand that they are not the same as previous answers.
The response should use each of the following four puzzle types at least once: Scramble, Fill-in-the-blank, Interwoven Strings, and Double Puzzle.
The response should not have any religious themes in the puzzles. For example, it should not use any specific references to religious holidays like Christmas, Hanukkah, etc

Response B does not include a specific reference. The AI model is flagging "YULELG" as containing YULE and that is a religious theme. The word is to be unscrambled and not reflective of the content, nor is it an actual word.
The response should have its puzzles progress in difficulty either in type of puzzle or challenge to solve. For example, its first puzzle should be simple while its last puzzle should be much harder.
Response B has such broken puzzles that scoring difficulty is impossible. The general types of its puzzles do progress from easier to harder so it scores minor issues.
The response should include a final puzzle in the form of an acrostic that uses the answers from the previous 6 puzzles to spell "DONATE".
The response should include the solution to the previous week's puzzle in all emails, except the first email.

The response should include the following sentiments in its final email: a thank you to participants for donating, wish them happy holidays, and list all answers for all puzzles including the acrostic.

The response should contain in its week 1 email template the following sentiments: announce the donation campaign for The Trevor Project, and a teaser that all six puzzles are connected to a final puzzle.

prompt:
I need some help getting content together for 3 rejection emails. Each rejection email only needs: a greeting, a blurb informing the applicant of their rejection, and a concise list of the requirements they were missing to perform the job correctly. Each should end with no more than two sentences informing them that, if they have questions, they can give us a call at: 555-666-7777. Make sure to thank them for their time. These emails should be kind. 

Below is the list of requirements our company has assigned to this position:
- Bachelor’s degree in Finance, Accounting, or Economics (Master’s/MBA preferred for senior roles).
- 2–4 years of experience in financial analysis, budgeting, forecasting, or a similar analytical role.
- MUST have experience with Excel, VLOOKUP/XLOOKUP, and data modeling. (must list all three!)
- Experience with financial reporting tools and ERP systems (e.g., SAP, NetSuite, Oracle, Workday).(must list all 4!)
- Experience in analyzing large datasets and identifying trends.
- Prior experience in presenting to large audiences.
- Prior experience working among multiple teams with 10+ individuals.
- Must be located in the San Francisco area.


Here are the lists of the three rejected candidates:

Kevin Smith
- Bachelor’s degree in Communications, obtained in 2019. 
- 2 years of experience in financial analysis, budgeting, and forecasting in my prior financial analyst role.
- 2 years of experience with Excel and data modeling.
- Used SAP, NetSuite, Oracle, Workday, and financial reporting tools in prior workspaces.
- Experience in analyzing large datasets and identifying trends.
- Prior experience in presenting to large audiences.
- Prior experience working individually, with some crossover to other teams. 
- Located in Oregon. 

Randy Beeks
- Bachelor’s degree in Finance.
- 1 year of experience in budgeting. 
- Prior experience with Excel, VLOOKUP/XLOOKUP, and data modeling.
- Experience with financial reporting tools and ERP systems (e.g., SAP, NetSuite, Oracle, Workday).
- Experience in analyzing small datasets and identifying trends. 
- Prior experience in presenting to teams of 10. 
- Prior experience working among multiple teams with 10+ individuals.
- Located in the San Francisco area.


Nessa Ralph
- Bachelor’s degree in Accounting.
- 4 years of experience in financial analysis in prior finance-based roles.
- Prior experience with Excel, VLOOKUP/XLOOKUP. 
- Experience with financial reporting tools and ERP systems (e.g., SAP, NetSuite, Oracle, Workday).
- Experience in analyzing large datasets. 
- Prior experience in presenting to large audiences.
- Prior experience working among multiple teams with 5-10 individuals. 
- Must be located in the San Francisco area.
rubrics: The response should list "identifying trends" as a missing requirement for Nessa Ralph.
The response should generate three separate rejection emails.
The response should address a separate rejection email to each of the three candidates: Kevin Smith, Randy Beeks, and Nessa Ralph.
The response should begin each rejection email with a greeting. For example, "Dear," or "Good afternoon".
The response should include a paragraph that informs each applicant they have been rejected for the position.
The response should thank each applicant (Kevin Smith, Randy Beeks, Nessa Ralph) for their time.
The response should use a kind tone when addressing the candidates. For example, using empathetic and professional language rather than blunt or cold statements.

The response should list "Prior experience working among multiple teams with 10+ individuals" as a missing requirement for Kevin Smith.
The response should list "Must be located in the San Francisco area" as a missing requirement for Kevin Smith.
The response should list "2–4 years of experience in financial analysis, budgeting, forecasting, or a similar analytical role" as a missing requirement for Randy Beeks.
The response should list "Experience in analyzing large datasets" as a missing requirement for Randy Beeks.
The response should list "Prior experience in presenting to large audiences" as a missing requirement for Randy Beeks.
The response should list "experience with data modeling" as a missing requirement for Nessa Ralph.
The response should list "Prior experience working among multiple teams with 10+ individuals" as a missing requirement for Nessa Ralph.
The response should end each email with a closing section that is two sentences or less.
The response should state in the closing section of each email that candidates can call 555-666-7777 with questions.

prompt:
I'm trying to streamline and make my workflows more efficient. I plan to have a few macros that paste pre-written, professional responses for certain IT tickets so I am not typing out the same things all the time. 

For one, I need a response that I can add at the end of the ticket interaction. It needs to inform the user that since their issues have been resolved, that the ticket will be moved into the Resolved state. The user has 48 hours to reply to the ticket to re-open it otherwise they will need to open a new ticket by emailing support@itadventures.com or calling 636-555-1234. 

Another will need to inform the user that due to several attempts to reach them, that their ticket will be moved to a Closed status. Tell them the same how to open a new ticket by emailing or calling the support number from the end of the previous response. 

Another should inform the user that their ticket does not fall into the scope of IT, but their ticket will be transferred to the correct department. Instead of making it generic, use <Insert Dept> in place of the "correct" in correct dept. This will make it easier for me to see it and fill in the relevant dept before sending the ticket off. Just to make sure I don't forget, add " ########## REPLACE DEPT NAME ##########" above and below this response so when it pastes into the email reply box, I have to quickly highlight and delete these to ensure I don't forget to enter the relevant dept. 

Last, I need a professional way to ask the user to restart their computer then let me know if they still have the issue. If I don't hear anything back after 48 hours, I'll move the ticket to Resolved which you should use the same ending as previous regarding the Resolved tickets closing and the user being able to re-open it. Ostensibly, I'm giving them 4 days to reply after restarting their computer. 

Please, bold the instances of support email, phone number, and ticket statuses (Resolved, Open, Closed) throughout the responses. And if you could, please use the formatting of (###) ###-#### for any phone numbers. Also, try and make each response 2 paragraphs of 3-4 sentences, except the 2nd and 3rd which could just be a single paragraph. I tend to unconsciously use the pronoun "we" when typing my own responses, so try and avoid that. 

All responses need to end with the following:

Best,

Bill Anted
Excellent IT Adventures Inc.
bill@itadventures.com
(636) 555-0011
rubrics: The response should include four macro responses.
The response should include a macro response that informs the user that their issues have been resolved.
The response should include at least two macro responses that inform the user they have 48 hours to reply to reopen the ticket.

The response should include four macro responses that end with the following:
Best,
Bill Anted
Excellent IT Adventures Inc.
bill@itadventures.com
(636) 555-0011
The response should format both numbers as (636) 555-1234 and (636) 555-0011.
The response should bold all instances of support@itadventures.com.
The response should bold both phone numbers: (636) 555‑1234 and (636) 555‑0011.
The response should not use the pronoun "we" in the responses.
The response should have a single paragraph for the body of the second macro, which informs the user about ticket closure due to inactivity.
The response should have a single paragraph for the body of the 3rd macro.
The response should include a macro template that informs the user their ticket will be moved to a Closed status due to inactivity.
The response should include a macro template that informs the user their ticket does not fall into the scope of the IT department.
The response should include the placeholder text <Insert Dept> in the 3rd macro, which is about transferring the ticket
The response should have the text ########## REPLACE DEPT NAME ########## surrounding the 3rd macro, the response about transferring the ticket.
The response should include a macro template that asks the user to restart their computer.
The response should bold the ticket status words Resolved and Closed.
The response should include two 3‑4 sentence paragraphs for the body of the 1st macro (the resolved ticket macro) and 4th macro (the reboot request macro) templates.

I need help scheduling volunteers for our upcoming community event. The event is from 10 AM to 2 PM, with an additional slot to serve from 8 AM to 10 AM for setup. All of our volunteers have signed up for a two-hour shift (at a minimum) or more.

I need to place each volunteer in a role that suits them best without short-changing any station. So, every station needs the required number of volunteers. We should give each volunteer their preference of serving location, unless doing so would place too many volunteers at one station or not enough in another station. In that case, volunteers should be placed anywhere else EXCEPT a location that they specifically requested NOT to be placed at.

A couple of special exceptions: the Christmas Carol station MUST be exactly who I’ve specified in the volunteer list. These CANNOT be moved to another station. The same goes for the Photo Booth. Charlene is our volunteer for that station - that CANNOT change. This is also true of the “Characters” station, the Story of Christmas Station, and the Social Media Team: volunteers must be EXACTLY who I’ve specified in the volunteer list. For these stations, they can have more than the required number of volunteers, seeing as they are specialized teams.

If the volunteer has signed up for an all-day commitment, they should stay at their station for the entire event. However, if the volunteer is only scheduled for a shift, they must be replaced.

Please create a volunteer layout in the following format. If you could please use bolding for the station numbers/titles, and a header for the shift label, that would really help me organize this well.

SETUP SHIFT: 8 AM - 10 AM
VOLUNTEER 1:
VOLUNTEER 2:
VOLUNTEER 3:
etc…

STATION #: TITLE
VOLUNTEER 1:
VOLUNTEER 2:
VOLUNTEER 3:
etc…

SHIFT 2: 12 PM - 2 PM
STATION #: TITLE
VOLUNTEER 1:
VOLUNTEER 2:
VOLUNTEER 3:
etc…

I have two lists for you below. One is a list of stations and their names, as well as how many volunteers we need at that station. We need that number of volunteers present for the entire day - so even as shifts change, we must have that number of volunteers present at those stations at all times. If we have a surplus of volunteers (more than enough to fill every role during that shift), then we can have more volunteers than required.

The second list is a list of all the volunteers that we have signed up. This second list contains their preferences regarding where they want to or don’t want to serve, and what shift they have signed up for. If I have them listed as “ALL DAY,” they are available for all three shifts (SETUP, SHIFT 1, SHIFT 2). 

If we do not have enough volunteers for any station and/or portion of the day, please tell me how many volunteers we are lacking and where, as well as for which shift. Also, let me know how many people are planning to be there for the set up shift.

We also need one person labeled as a FLOATER. This person doesn't go in any station, but they are on hand for bathroom breaks, etc.

Lastly, in a separate section at the end, please draft me up a quick email. We'll send this out to the rest of our volunteer database asking for help - I'd like that email to kindly invite everyone to serve at the Christmas Community Event on Saturday, December 13th. prompt:
I need help writing the capstone project for my English degree. I want to take the novel Their Eyes Were Watching God by Zora Neale Hurston, and analyze it in relation to a more contemporary work which isn't in the realm of literature. I was thinking that it would go along well with an August Wilson play. You're going to help me brainstorm different ways I can go about doing this.

Take a look at this excerpt from the opening of Their Eyes Were Watching God:

"Ships at a distance have every man’s wish on board. For some they
come in with the tide. For others they sail forever on the horizon, nev-
er out of sight, never landing until the Watcher turns his eyes away in
resignation, his dreams mocked to death by Time. That is the life of
men.
Now, women forget all those things they don’t want to remember,
and remember everything they don’t want to forget. The dream is the
truth. Then they act and do things accordingly.
So the beginning of this was a woman and she had come back from
burying the dead. Not the dead of sick and ailing with friends at the
pillow and the feet. She had come back from the sodden and the
bloated; the sudden dead, their eyes flung wide open in judgment.
The people all saw her come because it was sundown. The sun was
gone, but he had left his footprints in the sky. It was the time for sit-
ting on porches beside the road. It was the time to hear things and
talk. These sitters had been tongueless, earless, eyeless conveniences
all day long. Mules and other brutes had occupied their skins. But
now, the sun and the bossman were gone, so the skins felt powerful
and human. They became lords of sounds and lesser things. They
passed nations through their mouths. They sat in judgment.
Seeing the woman as she was made them remember the envy they
had stored up from other times. So they chewed up the back parts of
their minds and swallowed with relish. They made burning statements
with questions, and killing tools out of laughs. It was mass cruelty. A
mood come alive. Words walking without masters; walking altogether
like harmony in a song."

Identify how gendered language is used (and where it explicitly isn't used in relation to describing people) in this section using a numbered list. Then, I want you to come up with the first half of the thesis that I'll be using for this project. It should have something to do with the use of gendered language in this excerpt along with the theme of community, social life, and race. For each instance of your numbered list, write a sentence in a summary paragraph that describes your initial thesis more in depth and in relation to what you identified.

After that, select three August Wilson plays that I could potentially use in comparison to the novel. Each should have its own header with the title of the play in italics and the year it was written. Under that, use a few bullet points to highlight the main features of the play that relate and resonate to the themes of the novel / the thesis you've put forth. Then, based on these points, provide a revised thesis that takes elements from the original and puts them in dialogue with the Wilson play you've selected. Each revised thesis should mention both the title of the novel and the play you're comparing it to. Proceeding from that, each section should end with a few explicitly stated themes (in bold) that a comparison of the two works reveal, along with an explanation of where your comparison is coming from.

End with a conclusion paragraph (separated by a header) that sums up the major themes covered in the Wilson plays and how they can directly connect with the information provided in the excerpt I've included at the beginning of this prompt.
rubrics: The response should identify in a numbered list where gendered language is and isn't used in the provided text. The uses of gendered / non-gendered language include: men's dreams, women's dreams, the male personification of the sun, the mention of "the bossman", the female protagonist, the non-gendered community.

The response should form an initial thesis on the excerpt from 'Their Eyes Were Watching God' centered around the use of gendered language and the themes of community, social life, and race. For example, it could present a thesis on how the protagonist's identity relies on forming her own independence in the face of the Black community which often judges her.

P R O C E E D I N G S
(11:07 a.m.)
CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: We will hear
argument next in Case 20-444, United States
versus Gary.
Mr. Ellis.
ORAL ARGUMENT OF JONATHAN Y. ELLIS
ON BEHALF OF THE PETITIONER
MR. ELLIS: Mr. Chief Justice, and may
it please the Court:
The Fourth Circuit's automatic vacatur
rule for forfeited Rehaif plea colloquy errors
is flatly inconsistent with this Court's
repeated recognition that even the most
fundamental rights can be forfeited and that a
court of appeals should recognize a forfeited
claim only on a case-by-case basis in
exceptional circumstances.
The Court should reverse for two
principal reasons. First, Rehaif errors are not
automatically or even generally prejudicial.
Being convicted of a felony is not the sort of
life event that one is ordinarily unaware of or
forgets. In the mine-run of cases, as it is
here, it would be implausible that a defendant

4

who pleaded guilty to possessing a gun as a
felon would have insisted on going to trial if
he'd only known that the government would have
to prove that he knew he was -- had previously
been convicted of such a serious crime.
And, second, there's no exception from
plain-error review for claims that were
foreclosed by circuit precedent at the time of
the district court's proceeding. This Court's
decisions in Puckett and Johnson rightly
recognize that the Court lacks authority to
create such an atextual exception out of whole
cloth, and those holdings equally apply here.
Plain-error review is not an absolute
bar to relief. As demonstrated by the
experience of every other court of appeals in
the wake of this Court's decision in Rehaif,
courts can and should grant relief under that
standard in cases where a Rehaif error has truly
worked an injustice.
The Fourth Circuit's per se rule would
thus only serve to undermine the careful balance
between judicial efficiency and fairness
established by the Federal Rules and to provide
a windfall to defendants like Respondent, whose

5

convictions were and remain fundamentally fair.
The Court should reverse the decision
below, hold that forfeited Rehaif plea colloquy
claims are subject to the same case-specific
plain-error review as any other forfeited claim,
and make clear that Respondent cannot make that
showing.
I welcome the Court's questions.
CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: Mr. Ellis,
under the government's theory, does it matter
which element a district court omits during the
plea colloquy, or does the omission of an
element never constitute structural error?
MR. ELLIS: We don't think the
omission of an element ever constitutes
structural error. And we don't think that --
that any omission of an element would -- would
warrant a per se approach to plain-error review.
We think the Court's decision in Henderson v.
Morgan and Bousley are pretty -- are instructive
on that point.
Now the -- the nature of the element
might -- would inform both the prong 3 analysis
as to whether the defendant can show prejudice
and per se -- and the prong 4 analysis, so we

6

don't think it justifies a -- a per se rule.
CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: So, if a judge
-- a district court advises the defendant during
the plea colloquy that murder is a strict
liability offense and, you know, it doesn't
matter whether he has the intent to kill or not,
you think that -- you don't have a per se rule
there, in a situation like that, that that would
be structural error?
MR. ELLIS: No, Your Honor, we don't
think that would be structural error. I think
that is pretty analogous actually to the -- the
facts at issue in the Henderson v. Morgan case,
where the defendant -- the court didn't inform
the -- the -- the defendant that he had to have
the intent to kill for a second-degree murder
conviction. And even there, the court didn't
grant relief without noting that it was --
couldn't be harmless beyond a reasonable doubt.
The structural errors are -- are a
limited class, and they are those errors that
really go to the overall structure of the
proceeding and not a discrete error within it.
And that includes -- serious errors don't
qualify as structural errors. That doesn't mean

7

a defendant can't show prejudice on a
case-specific basis, but it does mean that --
that it should be required to do so.
CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: What if it's
just not one element but two elements, three
elements? Does it matter?
MR. ELLIS: So, you know --
CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: There's no --
no structural error if, you know, there are four
elements of the offense and the judge leaves out
three of them?
MR. ELLIS: So, you know, this Court's
decision in Dominguez Benitez at Footnote 10
suggests that there might be some structural
errors in the plea colloquy context. It pointed
there to the decision in Boykin v. Alabama. You
know, that -- that's pretty far afield of what
we have here. It's not even just an element
problem.
In that case, the defendant pleaded
guilty without being asked a single question
about the nature -- to make sure he understood
the nature of the charges or the consequences or
the rights he was giving up. We do think, you
know, that -- that that might rise to a

8

structural error.
Something short of that, you know,
it's going to be a harder case than the one
here. I think the Court grappled with the same
sort of problem in Neder, where Justice Scalia
made a similar argument in dissent. And what
the Court said there was, you know, we're --
we're not going to go take this "penny in for a
penny in per pound" approach. We're not going
to categorize all element errors as structural
errors just because there might be hard cases at
the margins.
And the last thing I'd say about that
is we haven't seen cases that sort of press that
line to date, and I think there's good reason
for that. As you get more and more egregious
errors, it's just not going to matter if you
label it structural or not. A defendant's going
to be able to show -- make a prejudice showing.
CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: Thank you,
counsel.
Justice Thomas.
JUSTICE THOMAS: Thank you, Mr. Chief
Justice.
Counsel, would you briefly comment on

9

Respondent's harmless-error review approach to
this case?
MR. ELLIS: So I think you're --
you're referring to the Respondent's argument
that he shouldn't have to satisfy plain-error
review?
JUSTICE THOMAS: Yeah.
MR. ELLIS: So that is obviously an
issue that he didn't raise below and is raising
for the first point -- first time here. We
think the Court has discretion to reach it, and
we -- we think it's flatly contrary to the
Court's decision in Johnson.
The Court in Johnson and Puckett
recognized both that the Court doesn't have
authority to create exceptions to the text of
52(b), and the text of 52(b) doesn't admit of
any exception for a futile exception. In
Johnson, the Court -- there was near universal
circuit precedent against the decision at the
time when the error was waived, and still the
Court subjected it to -- to plain-error review.
The way it --
JUSTICE THOMAS: I --
MR. ELLIS: -- accounted for that in

10

-- in Johnson was, at the second prong of
plain-error review, it said that the -- the
Court's going to analyze the plainness of the
error based on the -- the law at the time of
appeal. And that means that even in a -- in a
-- in a circumstance like that, where you
forfeited a claim that was barred by circuit
precedent, you can still get relief under
plain-error review. You just have to satisfy
the third and fourth prongs.
We think that's the right -- the
balance, and the Court should reaffirm that
approach here.
JUSTICE THOMAS: Can you think of -- I
may have missed this in your discussion with the
Chief Justice, but can you think of any error
that would -- would require automatic vacatur
under plain error?
MR. ELLIS: Under plain error? No,
Your Honor, the Court hasn't identified one.
And what it has said repeatedly in Young and in
Puckett is that the -- that a per se approach to
plain error is flawed.
You know, the -- the -- the -- the
rules of plain error are intended to set up a

11

system where you are encouraged and incentivized
to raise your claims in a timely manner and then
provide a safety valve for courts of appeals to
exercise their discretion to recognize a
forfeited -- a forfeited claim when there has
been a showing of prejudice and when there -- it
would undermine the fairness and integrity of
judicial proceedings not to do so. But we don't
think there's a per se rule for -- for any type
of error.
JUSTICE THOMAS: Thank you.
CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: Justice
Breyer.
JUSTICE BREYER: No. Thank you very
much. I have no questions.
CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: Justice Alito.
JUSTICE ALITO: If we were to rule for
Mr. Gary in this case, do you have an estimate
of the number of cases pending in the courts of
appeals or before this Court that would be
affected?
MR. ELLIS: So we -- we noted in our
brief there's -- there are 80 courses -- cases
being held, about 82 cases being held out of the
Fourth Circuit, the only circuit to not apply

12

the normal plain-error standards here, that
would be affected.
That's -- obviously, the Court's
decision would have broader effect across the
board, and we don't have a -- I can't give you
an estimate of that number of cases.
What I -- what I can point out is that
922(g) prosecutions are among the most common in
the federal system. In 2019, we cited a study
on page 42 of our opening brief, there were --
they accounted for nearly 10 percent or,
actually, I think at least over 10 percent of
all federal prosecutions, that was 7500 cases.
And -- and so, you know, the -- the --
Gary's rule here was -- would require automatic
vacatur of all those claims in which they're
asserted on direct appeal. I'd also point out
that, you know, whatever the burden is as a
matter -- a quantitative matter, qualitatively,
it just doesn't make any sense.
The other circuits, in the ordinary
principles of plain-error review, allow
defendants who are actually harmed by a Rehaif
error to get relief under plain-error review.
And so, really, the Fourth Circuit's per se rule

13

has the -- the effect of just catching those
cases where a defendant can't make a plausible
claim, like this one, that it would have made a
difference in the proceeding.
JUSTICE ALITO: Well, the Respondent
suggests that automatic vacatur in cases like
this one pose a significant burden on the
judiciary because most defendants will readily
plead guilty again. Is that true?
MR. ELLIS: It's hard to predict what
defendants will do. I guess the fact that
they're asserting it on appeal suggests that
they're not intending to do the exact same thing
they did the first time, even if, had the error
been raised, they would have.
You know, I -- I think that as far as
concerns about counsel raising a -- a litany of
futile objections, I'd say two things. The
first is that Johnson already dealt with that.
As I noted, that very argument was made in
Johnson. The Court agreed that it was a
legitimate concern but held that the right
approach was to make plain error -- the second
prong of plain error turn on the law at the time
of appeal.

14

And that means that you're not
foreclosed entirely when there's a change of
law, but you still have to make a prejudice
showing. And in the wake of that, we haven't
seen a litany of futile objections being raised.
I think that's good reason.
Defense counsel have -- have all the
incentive to focus on claims that might actually
make a difference, and they can know that even
for forfeited claims where there's a change of
law, they can -- their client can get relief if
it made -- under plain-error review if it really
made a difference in working an injustice.
JUSTICE ALITO: Thank you.
CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: Justice
Sotomayor.
JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR: Counsel, this is a
very different kind of case than our other
plain-error cases because, in our other cases,
the defendant had a reason for putting forth a
defense. So whether it was Neder, the defendant
knew that someone had to find materiality. It
was the same thing in Johnson.
But this is the kind of case where no
defendant knew that there could be an actual

15

defense at all. So why wouldn't we find that a
structural error? You're omitting the
requirement of an offense at all. And even if
we found it to be structural error under prong
3, why wouldn't you win under prong 4?
Because assuming that a court can look
at the entire record under prong 4, here, the
defendant admitted to the probation officer that
he -- and to the court, I believe, that he knew
he was a felon. So don't you win either way?
MR. ELLIS: We do. We agree that we
win either way. I think Johnson and Cotton make
crystal clear that even if you decide this kind
of error is a structural error, that it still
has to satisfy prong 4, and -- and I agree
entirely with the premise of your question, Your
Honor, that the defendant here would lose on
prong 4.
That said, I -- I don't think it is
right to call this a structural error.
You know, you alluded to the fact that -- that
the -- the Respondent's argument that he
wouldn't have an opportunity or incentive to
challenge the -- the -- the evidence here as to
his knowledge. I don't think that's just --

16

that's accurate as a -- a general matter.
You know, the evidence we're relying
on here is from the PSR in sentencing, his own
statement, as you point out. You know,
defendants have --
JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR: Do you have --
MR. ELLIS: -- every incentive --
JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR: Excuse me,
counsel. Do you have the same answer to the
questions posed earlier about the defendant who
really didn't know or have an opportunity to
create a record?
Do you agree that we should look at
those cases, even in a guilty plea, as different
than in the normal situation that a defendant
should be able to proffer evidence before the
appellate court?
MR. ELLIS: So we haven't gotten into
the record questions here. I -- I would say a
couple things about that.
First, we know at least with regard to
the record before the district court, that's --
that's entirely open on --
JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR: No, no, I'm not --
MR. ELLIS: -- in a case like this --

17

JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR: -- I'm not asking
you that because it never gets back to the
district court unless the appellate court says
that there was an error that sends the case
back. I'm asking the question as if a defendant
didn't know and didn't put into the record a
plausible defense.
Do you agree with your colleague in --
in Greer that that defendant could proffer that
in the appellate -- to the appellate court?
MR. ELLIS: Yes, Your Honor. We
have -- we have no objection to a -- a -- a
defendant offering that up, proffering that on
the first instance to a court of appeals in that
instance.
JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR: Thank you,
counsel.
CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: Justice Kagan.
JUSTICE KAGAN: Mr. Ellis, when you
were answering the Chief Justice's hypotheticals
earlier, you said that structural errors really
all go to the overall structure of the
proceeding and that's why none of the
hypotheticals he gave you were, in fact,
instances of structural error.

18

But I had thought that there was a
different category of structural error where
what we were looking at was some interest that
was unrelated to whether there was an erroneous
conviction and, in particular, a category where
we were concerned with autonomy interests, with
the ability of a defendant to make his own
choices.
And in some of those hypotheticals
that the Chief Justice was giving you, I would
have thought that there was no such ability to
make your own choices, that you have so little
information in cases like that that the autonomy
interest is raised to a very high level.
So I'm -- I'm curious as to your
response to that.
MR. ELLIS: Sure, Your Honor. So I --
I agree with you that the Court in -- in Weaver
in particular identified as one reason why a
case -- an error might be a structural one is
that it protects an error different than the --
the conviction, and -- and it specifically
flagged autonomy.
I'd say first that, you know, what
Weaver went on to say is that that sort of error

19

is still not the kind that should remove --
relieve a defendant of his requirement to show
prejudice and certainly wouldn't go to the
fourth prong.
Now, as to whether this kind of error
is an autonomy -- protects an autonomy interest,
I think -- I think not. I think the Court --
where the Court's found autonomy-based
structural errors, been pretty narrow
circumstances. So think about McCoy, where the
Court held that a defendant's autonomy interest
was violated where their counsel conceded guilt
over their objection.
But, in McCoy, the Court distinguished
that instance from where counsel conceded guilt
without an objection.
JUSTICE KAGAN: Well, go back, Mr.
Ellis, to the Chief Justice's hypothetical, then
maybe to a couple of -- of -- of different ones.
You know, suppose a defendant pleaded guilty
without being informed of any of the elements of
the offense. He didn't really even know what
crime he was pleading to.
Would that be structural error because
it interfered with his autonomy interest?

20

MR. ELLIS: So our view is no, that
autonomy -- those sort of autonomy interests as
those seen with McCoy are really ones where
the -- either the court or the counsel has taken
an interest over the express objection of a --
of a defendant in a case.
JUSTICE KAGAN: Well, how would he
even know what to object to if he -- if he
didn't know anything about what the crime was?
I mean, how can a defendant make the choice to
plead guilty if he doesn't know what he's
pleading to? I would have thought that that's
pretty non-autonomous decision-making.
MR. ELLIS: I -- I -- I'm not
disputing the fact that there is some autonomy
here when you're not being made -- a completely
knowing choice. The problem with taking that
sort of a view of a structural error is that it
would -- it would suggest a sort of unique error
in the plea colloquy context, and informing of
-- a defendant of his knowledge would risk being
an autonomous -- a structural error.
Either way, I think, Your Honor, what
I was saying before, I think what Weaver says is
that even in that case, you're going to need to

21

show prejudice, and we know from Johnson and
Cotton that you're going to need to show the
fourth prong. So I don't think you have to
definitively answer that question here.
I also think even if you think there
are some plea colloquy errors, as I noted to the
Chief Justice, that would be structural, be it
for autonomy reasons or others, we're not
getting close to that here. And -- and we -- we
don't think it's really evident on this --
JUSTICE KAGAN: Thank you, Mr. Ellis.
MR. ELLIS: Thank you.
CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: Justice
Gorsuch.
JUSTICE GORSUCH: I have no questions
at this time.
CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: Justice
Kavanaugh.
JUSTICE KAVANAUGH: No additional
questions.
CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: Justice
Barrett.
JUSTICE BARRETT: None from me either.
CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: A minute to
wrap up, Mr. Ellis.

22

MR. ELLIS: Thank you, Mr. Chief
Justice.
So, as I was just discussing with
Justice Kagan, I think there -- there are -- we
acknowledge there are hard questions here in
this case about precisely where to draw the line
between discrete plea colloquy errors, like the
one here, and a more fundamental breakdown in
the process where relief should be available
under even plain-error review.
But wherever one might draw that line,
this case falls far short of it. When
Respondent possessed the weapons at issue here,
he'd been convicted of seven different crimes
punishable by more than a year in prison, he'd
spent multiple years in prison, he'd been
released months before. He knew that he was not
supposed to possess a gun.
And in that respect, Defendant -- or
Respondent's circumstances are not atypical of
922(g)(1) defendants across the country. Every
other court of appeals has been able to apply
the ordinary principles of plain-error review to
distinguish between cases like this one, where
relief would do nothing but award a windfall to

23

a defendant whose conviction is fundamentally
fair, and those rare circumstances, where Rehaif
error has worked an injustice.
All we're asking is the Court reaffirm
that well-settled approach.
CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: Thank you,
counsel.
Mr. Fisher.
ORAL ARGUMENT OF JEFFREY L. FISHER
ON BEHALF OF THE RESPONDENT
MR. FISHER: Thank you, Mr. Chief
Justice, and may it please the Court:
The due process error here requires
automatic reversal for two reasons, first,
because the error is structural. A core aspect
of the autonomy every defendant must be afforded
is the ability to decide whether to contest the
government's allegations or, instead, to
relinquish one's physical liberty without trial
and submit to a term of imprisonment.
Failing to advise a defendant of the
complete charge against him necessarily deprives
him of the ability to make that grave choice
knowingly and intelligently. Indeed, it would
trample the framers' vision of free will to

24

enforce a guilty plea where the only facts the
defendant admitted do not even constitute a
crime and, where having now been advised of the
true nature of the charge, the defendant wants
to contest it.
Second, the plain-error doctrine does
not stand in the way of rem -- of remedying the
fundamental constitutional defect here. For
starters, the plain-error doctrine should not
even apply.
But even if Olano's test does apply,
the result would be the same. Structural errors
necessarily satisfy Olano's third prong as a
matter of plain text analysis, and in the words
of the fourth prong, it would seriously affect
the fairness, integrity, and public reputation
of judicial proceedings to allow a guilty plea
to stand without fair notice of the charge. And
that is especially so where the only reason for
withholding relief would be that the defendant
failed to make a pointless, totally formalistic
objection.
That leaves the government's complaint
about the practical consequences of having an
automatic vacatur rule here. They would be

25

slight. Our rule would do nothing more than
return an average of one Section 922 case to
each district judge, as the government's own
statistics demonstrate. That seems a small
price to pay for honoring what this Court has
long called the first and most universally
recognized rule of due process: fair notice of
the alleged conduct for which the government
seeks to put one of its citizens behind bars.
I welcome the Court's questions.
CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: Mr. Fisher, I
-- I want to talk just a moment about your
unanimous -- you know, the proposed futility
exception. What -- what does it take to satisfy
that? Unanimous view of the circuits but only
three circuits?
MR. FISHER: Well, Mr. Chief Justice,
obviously, all you would need to say in this
case is you -- is the unanimous view of the
circuits.
CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: Yeah, Mr.
Fisher, you understand that, you know, I'm not
talking about this case but a general rule.
MR. FISHER: Fair enough. We're --
we're -- we're -- we're making alternative

--
26

suggestions to the Court. I think the first
suggestion is that the Court could say plain
error does not apply when the unanimous view of
the circuits was against the defendant.
CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: So two -- two
MR. FISHER: That is a situation --
CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: -- two
circuits is unanimous. I mean, is that enough?
MR. FISHER: Oh, I'm sorry. Forgive
me. What I mean is every single court with
criminal jurisdiction --
CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: Oh, I see.
MR. FISHER: -- because that is a
situation where it is true futility. There's no
circuit split to put the defendant on notice
that the -- the judge on notice that the issue
is arguable, and there's no possibility that any
other court would adopt the alternative view.
And so, here, you have the truly unique
situation that the Court has never faced before
of true futility.
And my alternative submission, Mr.
Chief Justice, is that even if you don't think
that the plain-error doctrine should be set

27

aside here, at the very least, the futility of
the -- of the objection should be considered as
part of the prong 4 analysis. As the
conversation this morning in the first case
demonstrated, and I think the government's
position in our case also demonstrates, that is
a broad prong that looks at fundamental fairness
and the reputation of proceedings, and so, at
the very least, we think it would be unfair and
would bring disrepute on the judiciary to deny
relief in a situation where the defendant had no
reason to object and, in fact, it would have
been utterly pointless and formalistic to do so.
CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: You know, the
cases where we've held that it's not structural
error, I think, if you put them side by side
with yours, it's hard to say that yours is
necessarily stronger. You know, the judicial
improper participation in the negotiations, the
government's actual breach of the plea -- plea
agreement, if those aren't structural, why --
why is the error in this case?
MR. FISHER: The thing that sets this
case apart, Mr. Chief Justice -- well, actually,
there are two things.

28

The first is what Justice Kagan
mentioned, which is the autonomy interest at
stake. The Court has said that where the
defendant is deprived of a choice to make the
fundamental decisions about his own defense,
that is a different sort of error. And that is
the essence of what you have here, which is a
defendant who is unable to even decide whether
to challenge the government's case in a knowing
and intelligent manner.
And that leads to the second reason
that this is set apart, which is the first and
most elemental aspect of due process is fair
notice of the charge, and when that is deprived,
then everything else that follows cannot be
trusted.
CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS: Thank you,
counsel.

First, create a summary email for the parents that reassures them that safety is our top priority- it should open with "DA High is a safe and cooperative environment where open-mnded learnng is at the forefront of everthing we do." then two more paragraphs explaining that the teacher is on top of it, everyone's fine, zero tolerance policy, BUT don't be alarmist for the parents. We shouldn't be using the word "fight" or "violence", but instead something softer and bring every paragraph back to the idea of what the students are learning from the situation. For the district we need the more formal incident form structure:
- date (nov 18th 2025, but in ISO 8601) 
- school name
- classification (in this case physical violence)
- explanation (basically they were filming a challenge and fought over it, the whole class watched and everyone was involved using foul language, pushing etc., include grade level and that only minor injuries like scrapes occurred)
- remedial steps (quote from the email to parents, and make a generic statement about how we are enforcing classroom agreement)
Make sure in the report we aren't naming any names, and keep each section separate so i can transfer to the form more easily. 
If there's any information in the email that's not in the form or vice versa, include it separately for me at the end. They should have different tones, but it would be reasonable for the district to see the email and or for the parents to ask for the report, so they discrepancies should be in semantics only.

prompt: Help me design the fastest pinewood derby car using principles of physics and aerodynamics and which have been proven through trials and tests of various shapes and designs. As pinewood derby cars rely on maximizing potential energy and reducing friction, ensure that the axles are positioned in the ideal location to maximize the location of the center of gravity, thereby maximizing the potential energy and ultimately, the speed of the car. I am a very experienced adult, who has built many pinewood derby cars. The instructions can be very detailed. I have access to all large woodshop tools, as well as power hand tools such as scroll saws, skill saw, hand saws, dremels, drills, sanders, files, chivels, etc. I have a fully stocked shop. All Boy Scouts of America rules for the pinewood derby car apply. Provide step-by-step instructions on how to build the car, including templates to use to make cuts and modifications to the standard pine block used in the pinewood derby kits. The block is 7" long, 1.75 inches wide, and 1.25 inches tall and weighs 101 grams. I have access to tungsten weights for pinewood derby cars to help add weight to the right locations on the car. If the design required removal of material from the block (like cutting a wedge), recommend how much weight should be added and specify where and how, to reach the max allowable weight of 5 oz. Explicitly note where the center of gravity should be on the car, relative to the rear axle. The templates should be visual and provide detailed dimensions for the sides, top, bottom, front, and back of the pine block. Do not use ASCII text to create the templates. You should use something like SVGs to create the templates. The templates for modifying the pine block should be very concise. Specify what font sizes are used. Create a reference coordinate system for the block, choosing the front, left, bottom corner as the origin. No dimensions should be negative. All dimensions should be referenced using this coordinate system. Number each side/face of the pine block and specify which template applies to which face number. Or you can use letters to reference the faces, as long as it’s consistent and not confusing. The design and instructions should not require the purchase of any additional parts for the car, but should use all the pieces provided in the kit: the pine block, the 4 plastic wheels, and the 4 axles (nails). If there are additional tools that could be used to help in the assembly or setup of the car, I'd like to know what those are. I have access to a 3D printer (a Creality Ender 3 V2 Neo) that can be used to print parts or pieces for the car to help with aerodynamics or to print tools to help with setup and assembly. I can print in PLA, PETG, and TPU. Choose the most suitable material, depending on the application. I use Tinkercad for design and Ultimaker Cura for slicing. I can print up to 13 " x 13" x 13" If 3D printed parts or tools are suggested, please provide at least three links to example STL files that I can download, such as fenders, fairings, diffusers, or axle camber tools. However, do not recommend adding 3D printed parts on the car if it is not proven to make the car faster. If you do recommend a part, please provide links to the supporting evidence as to why that particular part will make the car faster. The purpose here is to build the absolute fastest car. Aesthetics don’t matter nor do I have a preference on how it looks. Every modification or addition must have a specific purpose to increase performance/speed. The build instructions should be printable as PDFs and should look like a set of Lego build instructions. The car will be run/raced on an aluminum pinewood derby track; specifically this one: https://microwizard.com/products/aluminum-pinewood-derby-track?variant=45989918605617. There are four lanes and the car will run in any or all of the lanes. The track is 40 feet long. The race is in three weeks, so provide a recommended schedule/timeline based on the ability to spend 1 hour a night working on the car and enough time to test the car and make any improvements or adjustments.
rubrics: The model should recommend the most suitable material from the provided list: PLA, PETG, or TPU for each suggested 3D-printed item.
The response should provide at least three distinct, functioning links to downloadable STL files for any suggested 3D-printed items.
The response should include tasks for testing the car and making adjustments.

The model should use language and level of detail in the instructions that is appropriate for an experienced adult with access to a full woodshop. For example, it can assume familiarity with tools like a scroll saw or drill press without explaining their basic operation.
The model should recommend a proven, fast design based on physics. For example, a wedge-shaped car.
The model should recommend a center of gravity in front of the rear axle to maximize potential energy. For example, between 0.5 inches and 2 inches in front of the rear axle.
The model should include visual (non‑ASCII) templates created with a format such as SVG.
The model should specify the font sizes used in the templates.
The model should create a reference coordinate system for the block, choosing the front‑left‑bottom corner as the origin.
The model should ensure all dimensions are referenced to a coordinate system whose origin is the front-left-bottom corner of the block.
The model should number each side/face of the pine block (or use consistent letters).
The model should map each provided template to a specific, labeled face of the car block (e.g., 'Template 1 applies to Face 3 (Top)').

The response should ensure the car design uses only the following parts: the pine block, 4 plastic wheels, 4 axles (nails), and tungsten weights. The design should not require purchasing any other parts that are attached to the car.

The model response should be structured as a document suitable for printing as a PDF. For example, it should use clear headings, numbered sections, and place visual templates logically within the text.

The model should produce instructions styled like a set of LEGO building instructions. For example, it should use numbered steps with primarily visual diagrams, lists of parts needed for each step, and minimal explanatory text.
The model should provide templates for each face of the pine block (sides, top, bottom, front, back).
The model should recommend how much weight to add to get the designed car up to 5 oz.
The model should specify the locations for adding weight using coordinates or clear diagrams showing where to drill holes.
The model should deliver a recommended schedule/timeline for the three‑week build with the constraint of only working 1 hour a day.
The model should only suggest design elements that increase performance. For example, it should not give instructions for painting the car for aesthetic reasons.

Painting the car does increase performance by allowing air to flow over it easier, reducing friction and drag. It is assumed and expected that the model would suggest steps and efforts that don't directly impact performance - such as printing out the templates.
The model should provide links to supporting evidence explaining why any recommended 3D-printed part improves speed.
The model should not recommend 3D printing car parts that don't increase the car's performance.

prompt:
I’m creating a grant application for my Nova Scotia-based band’s 2025 fall tour. The write-up portion of the application needs to include a budget proposal and three SMART goals related to the touring activities, as well as a description of our notable successes and current opportunities in the touring region. For the SMART goals, the program coordinator specifically said he wants each of the five metrics spelled-out and digestible at a glance rather than having to pore over long paragraphs of text. I want one of the goals to be to make at least an average of $700 per show in ticket revenue, one to increase our instagram follower count to at least 4500 from our current 3700, and one to make at least an average of $140 per show in merch sales. We're totally indie and don't work with any external booking agents or promoters, and we do all our own advertising via instagram and postering (budget and merch inventory will remain consistent with last year's, so don't make any claims about new items, new strategies, or increased advertising budget.) 

The grant will cover up to $5000 of eligible expenses, but only up to 50% of our total proposed budget. Gas will be a key eligible expense; we expect to do about 5000 km of driving and the grant will cover $0.50/km for gas. We’ll also budget for $200/night for the eligible expense of hotel costs after each show, except after the Ottawa show we’ll be staying for free with one of the bandmates’ family for two nights, and then we’ll be staying there again on our days off between Waterloo and Kingston. Per diems and artists’ fees are also eligible. We’re a three-piece and will allot a $50 per diem for each member throughout the tour, as well as paying ourselves a total $300 artist’s fee for each show. We can also include a grant administration fee as an eligible expense, up to 15% of the total budget, but I only want to include that if it’s necessary in order to max us out to be eligible for the full $5000.  

I need you to write up the SMART goals, as well as a proposed budget that should be presented as a table. Don’t include tables for anything else because it’ll be visually confusing. For the write-up of notable successes and current opportunities, highlight one new venue from the last tour at which we had a financially successful show and how we’re following up on that by returning this time, one new city we’re playing in that we haven’t played before, and one new-to-us venue in a city in which we’ve played before.

rubrics: The response should define exactly three distinct SMART goals.
The response should include a SMART goal to attain an average per-show ticket revenue of $700.
The response should include a SMART goal to attain a total Instagram follower count of 4500.
The response should include a SMART goal to attain an average per-show merch sales revenue of $140.

The response should use the market history data to support the SMART goals. For example, it could mention that the 1100 follower increase over the course of the Spring 2025 tour means that an 800 follower increase over the course of the Fall 2025 tour is precedented.
The response should spell out each letter for each SMART goal as Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, and Time-Bound.
The response should format each SMART goal in a digestible format rather than as a long paragraph. For example, it could use a bulleted list highlighting each SMART metric for each goal.
The response should format the budget section into a table.
The response should not include any tables other than the one for the budget.
The response should include a line in the budget for eligible gas expenses calculated at 5000km x $0.50 = $2500.
The response should include a line in the budget for hotel costs calculated as $200/night x 14 nights = $2800.

The nights a hotel is required and eligible as an expense are Saint John on the 8th, Quebec City on the 9th, Montreal on the 10th, Hamilton on the 13th, Toronto on the 14th, Waterloo on the 15th, Kingston on the 20th, Niagara Falls on the 21st, Oshawa on the 22nd, and Edmundston on the 23rd, 24th, 25th, 25th, and 27th, totalling 14 nights.

The response should include a line in the budget for a $300 artist's fee x 11 out-of-province shows = $3300. For example, it should not include the Halifax, New Glasgow, or Truro shows as being eligible for an artist's fee.

The response should include a line in the budget for a $50 per diem x 3 band members x 18 eligible days (November 7th, the day prior to the first out of province show, to November 24th, the day after the last out of province show) = $2700.
The response should not include an administration fee as a line in the budget.

The response should include a point in the notable successes and current opportunities section that highlights one venue from the Spring 2025 tour at which the band had a financially successful show and to which they will be returning again in this Fall 2025 tour. For example, it could choose from Quai des Brûmes in Montreal, Avant Garde in Ottawa, Doors Pub in Hamilton, and Midnight Run in Waterloo.

The response should include a point in the notable successes and current opportunities section that highlights one city on the schedule that the band has never visited before. For example, it could choose from Quebec City, Niagara, and Edmundston.

The response should include a point in the notable successes and current opportunities section that highlights one new venue on the Fall 2025 tour schedule in a city that the band has played in before. For example, it could choose from The Pilot in Toronto and Tommy's Diner in Kingston.

The criterion checkers are registering that the band has played Niagara before, which would make it a valid choice to fulfill this criterion, but the market history included in the prompt does not include any previous performances in Niagara.
The response should include a total project budget of at least $10,000.

The prompt states, "We can also include a grant administration fee as an eligible expense, up to 15% of the total budget, but *I only want to include that if it’s necessary in order to max us out to be eligible for the full $5000*" which implies the goal of reaching a $10,000 budget, since the user is trying to be eligible to receive the full $5000 and we know that "the grant will cover up to $5000 of eligible expenses, but only up to 50% of our total proposed budget."
The response should not mention that the band is working with any promoters or booking agents.
The response should not claim that the band will be changing its advertising or merchandise strategies compared to previous tours.

Falador Massacre

For in-game lore/storylines, write questions about backstory or quest.

For all questions, do not write about the same quest or skill twice. 

I would also like one final, bonus question. List 5 high value items, and players must put them in order of ascending price. High value in this context means 100 million gp or more as of 1st July 2024.

The questions should be randomised, except for the bonus question which should be at the end. The questions should be in a numbered list: 1-15, followed by Bonus Question. The answers should be given in a separate numbered list, with answer numbers corresponding to question number.

explanation/context (regular formatting)

The construction question mentioned is not relating to the mechanics of the skill: "What minor visual imperfection on the Construction skill icon sparked years of community memes and complaints before it was finally fixed?" This is clearly a player-lore related question as it talks about the community.

Answer (in bold)
Explanation (regular formatting)

Model B does not satisfy this.
The response should have exactly 1 of the 15 questions relating to the Order of Cabbage.

The response should have the bonus question instruct players to put 5 items in order of ascending price.
The response should contain exactly 2 out of 15 questions be about non-quest bosses. For example, questions about the Corporeal Beast or General Graardor.
Model 1 asks a question about the giant mole, which is a non-quest boss.
The response should not feature the same in-game skill in more than one question.
The response should contain exactly one question out of 15 about the Falador Massacre.
The response should have the questions randomized and not grouped by category (e.g., all lore questions together). For example, a lore question could be followed by a skill question.

The response should have five of the 15 questions be about player lore, with one question for each of the following topics: Falador Massacre, Zezima, Construction icon green pixel, Order of Cabbage, and Pay to PK Riot.
The response should have the five in‑game lore/story questions each be about a backstory element or a quest.

Response A has 5 back story / game lore questions: 2, 7, 10, 12, 14.

Response B only has 4: Q1, 6, 10, 15.
The response should ensure that all answers that do not need additional context consist of a single word or a short phrase.
The analyzers are implementing this criterion against answers that need additional explanation when it shouldn't be.

prompt:
Hello, I am the bookkeeper for a large regional coin dealer and we sell both coins and precious metals like gold and silver. I need your help to figure out which products we should purchase more of for our inventory to make the most money. However, some of the high-margin products, like popular and new issues, are limited in availability from our supplier. Specifically, we cannot get any additional access to silver eagles for the time being, which make up 80% of the "Silver & related dollars category". If a coin type has less than 5 units sold, it should not be restocked, unless the profit margin is greater than 30%. For all of our products, please also calculate the net profit and net profit per unit.  All of this information should be formatted in a table with bolded headings. If an item should be restocked because of its performance, but cannot because of availability, then write N/A as your recommendation. If a product should not be restocked, then explain why; otherwise, do not elaborate.
